Identifiable Shared Component Analysis of Unpaired Multimodal Mixtures

Subash Timilsina
Department of EECS
Oregon State University
Corvallis, OR 97331
timilsis@oregonstate.edu
&Sagar Shrestha
Department of EECS
Oregon State University
Corvallis, OR 97331
shressag@oregonstate.edu
&Xiao Fu
Department of EECS
Oregon State University
Corvallis, OR 97331
xiao.fu@oregonstate.edu
Abstract

A core task in multi-modal learning is to integrate information from multiple feature spaces (e.g., text and audio), offering modality-invariant essential representations of data. Recent research showed that, classical tools such as canonical correlation analysis (CCA) provably identify the shared components up to minor ambiguities, when samples in each modality are generated from a linear mixture of shared and private components. Such identifiability results were obtained under the condition that the cross-modality samples are aligned/paired according to their shared information. This work takes a step further, investigating shared component identifiability from multi-modal linear mixtures where cross-modality samples are unaligned. A distribution divergence minimization-based loss is proposed, under which a suite of sufficient conditions ensuring identifiability of the shared components are derived. Our conditions are based on cross-modality distribution discrepancy characterization and density-preserving transform removal, which are much milder than existing studies relying on independent component analysis. More relaxed conditions are also provided via adding reasonable structural constraints, motivated by available side information in various applications. The identifiability claims are thoroughly validated using synthetic and real-world data.

1 Introduction

The same data entities can often be represented in different feature spaces (e.g., audio, text and image), due to the variety of sensing modalities. Learning common latent components of data from multiple modalities is well-motivated in representation learning. The shared components are considered modality-invariant essential representations of data, which can often enhance performance of downstream tasks by shedding modality-specific noise [1, 2, 3, 4] and avoiding over-fitting [5, 6, 7].

A prominent theoretical aspect of shared component learning lies in identifiability of the components of interest. The literature posed an intriguing theoretical question [1, 2, 8]: If every modality of data is represented by a linear mixture of shared and private components with an unknown mixing system, are the shared components identifiable (up to acceptable ambiguities)? Such component identification problems are often nontrivial due to the ill-posed nature of any linear mixture model (see, e.g., [9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14]). Interestingly, the work [1] showed that using the classical canonical correlation analysis (CCA) provably find the shared components up to rotation and scaling. In fact, shared component identification from multimodal/multiview linear mixtures were considered in various contexts (see, e.g., [15, 16, 17, 18]), although some of these works did not model private components. The identifiability results in [1, 2] were generalized to nonlinear mixture models as well [4, 19]. The shared component identification perspective was also related to the success of representation learning in self-supervised learning (SSL) [6, 5, 7].

Nonetheless, the treatment in [1, 2] and the related works [17, 16, 15] all assumed that the cross-modality data are aligned (i.e., paired) according to their shared components. In many applications, such as cross-language information retrieval [20, 21, 22], domain adaptation [23, 24, 25], and biological data translation [26, 27], aligned cross-modality data are hard to acquire, if not outright unavailable. A natural question is: When the multimodal linear mixtures are unaligned, can the shared latent components still be provably identified under reasonably mild conditions?

Existing Studies. Theoretical characteristics of unaligned multimodal learning were studied under various settings. The work [28] considered a case where one modality is a linear transform of another modality, and showed that the linear transformation is potentially identifiable. The recent work [29] extended this model to a nonlinear transform setting. However, these works did not consider latent component modelsâ€”yet the latter are more versatile in many ways, e.g., facilitating one-to-many translations [30, 31]. The work [32] considered unaligned mixtures of shared and private components, but the assumptions (e.g., the availability of a large amount of modalities) to ensure identifiability may not be easy to satisfy. The most related work is perhaps [8]. But their approach also relied on somewhat stringent assumptions, e.g., that all the latent components are element-wise statistically independent with at most one component being Gaussian. This is because their procedure had to invoke the classical independent component analysis (ICA) [33].

Contributions. In this work, we provide a suite of sufficient conditions under which the shared components can be provably identified from unaligned multimodal linear mixtures up to reasonable ambiguities. The model and identification problem are referred to as unaligned shared component analysis (unaligned SCA) in the sequel.

(i) An Identifiable Learning Loss for Unaligned SCA. We propose to tackle the unaligned SCA problem by matching the probability distributions of linearly embedded multi-modal data. We show that under reasonable conditions, the linear transformations identifies the shared components up to the same ambiguities as those in the aligned case [1, 2]. The conditions are considerably milder compared to the existing unaligned SCA work [8].

(ii) Enhanced Identifiability via Structural Constraints. We come up with two types of structural constraints, motivated by available side information in applications, to further relax the identifiability conditions. Specifically, we look into cases where the multi-model data have similar linear mixing systems and cases where a few cross-domain aligned samples available. We show that by adding constraints accordingly, unaligned SCA are identiable under much milder conditions.

Our contributions primarily lie in identifiability analysis. Nonetheless, we also show the usefulness of our results in real-world applications, namely, cross-lingual word retrieval, genetic information alignment and image data domain adaptation. Particularly, it shows that our succinct multimodal linear mixture model can effectively post-process outputs of large foundation models (e.g., CLIP [34]) to improve data representations and enhance downstream task performance.

Notation. Notation definitions can be found in AppendixÂ A.

2 Background

Generative Model of Interest. Following the classical settings in [2, 1, 15, 16, 18], we consider modeling the multi-modal data as linear mixtures. More specifically, we adopt the model in [2, 1]that splits the latent representation of data into shared components and private components:

The goal of SCA boils down to finding linear operators to recover ğ’„ğ’„\bm{c}bold_italic_c to a reasonable extent.

Aligned SCA: Identifiability of CCA and Extensions. Learning ğ’„ğ’„\bm{c}bold_italic_c without knowing ğ‘¨(q)superscriptğ‘¨ğ‘\boldsymbol{A}^{(q)}bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a typical component analysis problem. Learning latent components from linear mixtures lacks identifiability in general, due to the bilinear nature of linear mixture models (LMMs) like ğ’™=ğ‘¨â¢ğ’›ğ’™ğ‘¨ğ’›\boldsymbol{x}=\boldsymbol{A}\boldsymbol{z}bold_italic_x = bold_italic_A bold_italic_z; see Sec.Â 5 for various component analysis frameworks dealing with the single-modality LMM. The works [1, 2] studied the identifiability of ğ’„ğ’„\boldsymbol{c}bold_italic_c under the model (1), using the assumption that the cross-modality samples share the same ğ’„ğ’„\bm{c}bold_italic_c are aligned. In particular, [1] formulated the ğ’„ğ’„\bm{c}bold_italic_c-identification problem as a CCA problem:

Unaligned SCA: Existing Result and Theoretical Gap. The work in [8] studied the identifiability of ğ’„ğ’„\bm{c}bold_italic_c under (1) when ğ’™(1)superscriptğ’™1\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ’™(2)superscriptğ’™2\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are unaligned. Their approach works under the condition that the elements of ğ³(q)=[ğœâŠ¤,(ğ©(q))âŠ¤]âŠ¤superscriptğ³ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptğœtopsuperscriptsuperscriptğ©ğ‘toptop\bm{z}^{(q)}=[\bm{c}^{\top},(\bm{p}^{(q)})^{\top}]^{\top}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ bold_italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are mutually statistically independent. There, ğ’›^(q)=ğš·(q)â¢ğšº(q)â¢ğ’›(q)superscript^ğ’›ğ‘superscriptğš·ğ‘superscriptğšºğ‘superscriptğ’›ğ‘\widehat{\bm{z}}^{(q)}=\bm{\Pi}^{(q)}\bm{\Sigma}^{(q)}\bm{z}^{(q)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_z end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Î£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is assumed to have been estimated by ICA, where ğš·(q)superscriptğš·ğ‘\bm{\Pi}^{(q)}bold_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğšº(q)superscriptğšºğ‘\bm{\Sigma}^{(q)}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT represent the scaling and permutation ambiguities, respectively, which cannot be removed by ICA. The work [8] assumed ğšº(q)=ğ‘°superscriptğšºğ‘ğ‘°\bm{\Sigma}^{(q)}=\bm{I}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_I by imposing a unit-variance assumption on all the zi(q)superscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘z_{i}^{(q)}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTâ€™s. Then, a cross-domain matching algorithm is used to match the shared elements in ğ’›^(1)superscript^ğ’›1\widehat{\bm{z}}^{(1)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_z end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ’›^(2)superscript^ğ’›2\widehat{\bm{z}}^{(2)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_z end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The formulation can be summarized as finding dCsubscriptğ‘‘Cd_{\rm C}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT pairs of non-repetitive (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j)( italic_i , italic_j ) such that ğ’†iâŠ¤â¢ğ’›^(1)superscriptsubscriptğ’†ğ‘–topsuperscript^ğ’›1\bm{e}_{i}^{\!\top\!}\widehat{\bm{z}}^{(1)}bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_italic_z end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ’†jâŠ¤â¢ğ’›^(2)superscriptsubscriptğ’†ğ‘—topsuperscript^ğ’›2\bm{e}_{j}^{\!\top\!}\widehat{\bm{z}}^{(2)}bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_italic_z end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have identical distributions, where ğ’†isubscriptğ’†ğ‘–\bm{e}_{i}bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the iğ‘–iitalic_ith unit vector. Denote c^m(1)=ğ’†imâŠ¤â¢ğ’›^(1)subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘1ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ’†topsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘šsuperscript^ğ’›1\widehat{c}^{(1)}_{m}=\bm{e}^{\!\top\!}_{i_{m}}\widehat{\bm{z}}^{(1)}over^ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_italic_z end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and c^m(2)=ğ’†jmâŠ¤â¢ğ’›^(2)subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘2ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ’†topsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘šsuperscript^ğ’›2\widehat{c}^{(2)}_{m}=\bm{e}^{\!\top\!}_{j_{m}}\widehat{\bm{z}}^{(2)}over^ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_italic_z end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for mâˆˆ[dC]ğ‘šdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘‘Cm\in[d_{\rm C}]italic_m âˆˆ [ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]. It can be shown that

c^m(q)=kâ¢cğ…â¢(m)(q),mâˆˆ[dC],formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript^ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘šğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ…ğ‘šğ‘šdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘‘C\displaystyle\widehat{c}^{(q)}_{m}=kc^{(q)}_{\bm{\pi}(m)},~{}m\in[d_{\rm C}],over^ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Ï€ ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m âˆˆ [ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] , (5)

where kâˆˆ{+1,âˆ’1}ğ‘˜11k\in\{+1,-1\}italic_k âˆˆ { + 1 , - 1 } and ğ…ğ…\bm{\pi}bold_italic_Ï€ is a permutation of {1,â€¦,dC}1â€¦subscriptğ‘‘C\{1,\ldots,d_{\rm C}\}{ 1 , â€¦ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } (see details in AppendixÂ E.2 summarized from [8]). This method effectively applies ICA to each modality, and thus the ICA identifiability conditions [33] have to met by ğ’™(1)superscriptğ’™1\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ’™(2)superscriptğ’™2\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT individually. However, if one only aims to extract ğš¯â¢ğ’„ğš¯ğ’„\bm{\Theta}\bm{c}bold_Î˜ bold_italic_c as in CCA, these assumptions appear to be overly stringent.

3 Proposed Approach

Unaligned SCA: Problem Formulation We assume that ğ’™(q)superscriptğ’™ğ‘\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTâ€™s are zero-mean. We use the notation from CCA in (3a). However, since no aligned samples are available, we replace the sample-level matching objective with a distribution matching (DM) module, as DM can be carried out without sample level alignment:

findfind\displaystyle{\rm find}\quadroman_find ğ‘¸(q)âˆˆâ„dCÃ—d(q),q=1,2,formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘Csuperscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘12\displaystyle\boldsymbol{Q}^{(q)}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}\times d^{(q)}},~{}q=% 1,2,bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_q = 1 , 2 , (6a)
subject to
ğ‘¸(q)â¢ğ”¼â¢[ğ’™(q)â¢(ğ’™(q))âŠ¤]â¢(ğ‘¸(q))âŠ¤=ğ‘°q=1,2.formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ’™ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptğ’™ğ‘topsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘topğ‘°ğ‘12\displaystyle\boldsymbol{Q}^{(q)}\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}(% \boldsymbol{x}^{(q)})^{\top}\right](\boldsymbol{Q}^{(q)})^{\top}=\bm{I}\quad q% =1,2.bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ğ”¼ [ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ( bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_I italic_q = 1 , 2 . (6b)

where â€œğ’–â¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢ğ’—ğ’–\xlongequalğ–½ğ’—\bm{u}\xlongequal{({\sf d})}\bm{v}bold_italic_u ( sansserif_d ) bold_italic_vâ€ means the distributions of ğ’–ğ’–\bm{u}bold_italic_u and ğ’—ğ’—\bm{v}bold_italic_v are the same.

The formulation in (6) can be realized using various distribution matching tools, e.g., maximum mean discrepancy (MMD) [36] and Wasserstein distance [37]. We use the adversarial loss:

minğ‘¸(1),ğ‘¸(2)â¡maxfâ¡ğ”¼ğ’™(1)â¢logâ¡(fâ¢(ğ‘¸(1)â¢ğ’™(1)))+ğ”¼ğ’™(2)â¢logâ¡(1âˆ’fâ¢(ğ‘¸(2)â¢ğ’™(2)))+Î»â¢âˆ‘q=12â„›â¢(ğ‘¸(q)),subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¸1superscriptğ‘¸2subscriptğ‘“subscriptğ”¼superscriptğ’™1ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¸1superscriptğ’™1subscriptğ”¼superscriptğ’™21ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¸2superscriptğ’™2ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘12â„›superscriptğ‘¸ğ‘\displaystyle\min_{{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(1)},{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(2)}}\max_{f}~{}% \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}}\log\left(f({\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(1)}{% \boldsymbol{x}}^{(1)})\right)+\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}}\log\left(1-f({% \boldsymbol{Q}}^{(2)}{\boldsymbol{x}}^{(2)})\right)+\lambda\sum_{q=1}^{2}{\cal R% }\left({\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}\right),roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ğ”¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( italic_f ( bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) + roman_ğ”¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( 1 - italic_f ( bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) + italic_Î» âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R ( bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (6g)

The first and second terms comprise the adversarial loss from GAN [38]. It finds ğ‘¸(q)superscriptğ‘¸ğ‘\bm{Q}^{(q)}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to confuse the best-possible discriminator f:â„dCâ†’â„:ğ‘“â†’superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘Câ„f:\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_f : roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ roman_â„, where fğ‘“fitalic_f is represented by a neural network in practice. It is well known that the minimax optimal point of the first two terms is attained when (LABEL:eq:dm) is met [38]. We use â„›â¢(ğ‘¸(q))=â€–ğ‘¸(q)â¢ğ”¼â¢[ğ’™(q)â¢(ğ’™(q))âŠ¤]â¢(ğ‘¸(q))âŠ¤âˆ’ğ‘°â€–F2â„›superscriptğ‘¸ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ’™ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptğ’™ğ‘topsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘topğ‘°2F{\cal R}({\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)})=\|{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}\mathbb{E}[{% \boldsymbol{x}}^{(q)}({\boldsymbol{x}}^{(q)})^{\top}]({\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)})^% {\top}-\bm{I}\|^{2}_{\rm F}caligraphic_R ( bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = âˆ¥ bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ğ”¼ [ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ( bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_I âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to â€œliftâ€ the constraints. This way, the learning criterion in (6g) can be readily handled by any off-the-shelf adverserial learning tools.

Identifiability of Unaligned SCA As we saw in TheoremÂ 4, CCA identifies ğ‘¸^(q)â¢ğ’™(q)=ğš¯â¢ğ’„superscript^ğ‘¸ğ‘superscriptğ’™ğ‘ğš¯ğ’„\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}\bm{c}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ bold_italic_c where ğš¯âˆˆâ„dCÃ—dCğš¯superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘‘C\bm{\Theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}\times d_{\rm C}}bold_Î˜ âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT under the settings of aligned SCA. Establishing a similar result for unaligned SCA is much more challenging. First, it is unclear if (LABEL:eq:dm) could disentangle ğ’„ğ’„\bm{c}bold_italic_c from ğ’‘(q)superscriptğ’‘ğ‘\boldsymbol{p}^{(q)}bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In general, ğ‘¸(q)â¢ğ’™(q)superscriptğ‘¸ğ‘superscriptğ’™ğ‘\boldsymbol{Q}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT could still be a mixture of ğ’„ğ’„\bm{c}bold_italic_c and ğ’‘(q)superscriptğ’‘ğ‘\bm{p}^{(q)}bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT yet (LABEL:eq:dm) still holds (e.g., when both ğ’„ğ’„\boldsymbol{c}bold_italic_c and ğ’‘(q)superscriptğ’‘ğ‘\boldsymbol{p}^{(q)}bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are Gaussian.)

Second, even when the disentanglement is attained via enforcing (LABEL:eq:dm) and we have ğ‘¸(q)â¢ğ’™(q)=ğš¯(q)â¢ğ’„superscriptğ‘¸ğ‘superscriptğ’™ğ‘superscriptğš¯ğ‘ğ’„\bm{Q}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}^{(q)}\bm{c}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c, in general it does not hold that ğš¯(1)=ğš¯(2)superscriptğš¯1superscriptğš¯2\bm{\Theta}^{(1)}=\bm{\Theta}^{(2)}bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This is because ğš¯(1)â¢ğ’„â¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢ğš¯(2)â¢ğ’„superscriptğš¯1ğ’„\xlongequalğ–½superscriptğš¯2ğ’„\bm{\Theta}^{(1)}\boldsymbol{c}\xlongequal{({\sf d})}\bm{\Theta}^{(2)}% \boldsymbol{c}bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c ( sansserif_d ) bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c where ğš¯(1)â‰ ğš¯(2)superscriptğš¯1superscriptğš¯2\bm{\Theta}^{(1)}\neq\bm{\Theta}^{(2)}bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can still be perfectly met (e.g., when â„™ğš¯(q)â¢ğ’„subscriptâ„™superscriptğš¯ğ‘ğ’„\mathbb{P}_{\bm{\Theta}^{(q)}\bm{c}}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is symmetric Gaussian in Fig.Â 2 ). However, ğš¯(1)â‰ ğš¯(2)superscriptğš¯1superscriptğš¯2\bm{\Theta}^{(1)}\neq\bm{\Theta}^{(2)}bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT means that the extracted representations from the two modalities are not matched. This creates challenges for applications like cross-domain information retrieval, language translation, or domain adaptation.

Our intuition is as follows: If the two distributions â„™ğ’„,ğ’‘(1)subscriptâ„™ğ’„superscriptğ’‘1\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{c},\boldsymbol{p}^{(1)}}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c , bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â„™ğ’„,ğ’‘(2)subscriptâ„™ğ’„superscriptğ’‘2\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{c},\boldsymbol{p}^{(2)}}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c , bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are very different, then ğ‘¸(1)â¢ğ’™(1)â¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢ğ‘¸(2)â¢ğ’™(2)superscriptğ‘¸1superscriptğ’™1\xlongequalğ–½superscriptğ‘¸2superscriptğ’™2\boldsymbol{Q}^{(1)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}\xlongequal{({\sf d})}\boldsymbol{Q}^{% (2)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( sansserif_d ) bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT cannot hold unless ğ‘¸(q)â¢ğ‘¨(q)=[ğš¯(q),ğŸ]superscriptğ‘¸ğ‘superscriptğ‘¨ğ‘superscriptğš¯ğ‘0\boldsymbol{Q}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{A}^{(q)}=[\bm{\Theta}^{(q)},\bm{0}]bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_0 ]. We use the following to characterize such difference between the joint distributions:

Assumption 1 (Modality Variability).

For any two linear subspaces ğ’«(q)âŠ‚â„dC+dP(q),q=1,2formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ’«ğ‘superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘Csuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‘Pğ‘ğ‘12\mathcal{P}^{(q)}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}+d_{\rm start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_q = 1 , 2, with â„™ğœ,ğ©(1)â¢[kâ¢ğ’œ(1)]â‰ â„™ğœ,ğ©(2)â¢[kâ¢ğ’œ(2)]subscriptâ„™ğœsuperscriptğ©1delimited-[]ğ‘˜superscriptğ’œ1subscriptâ„™ğœsuperscriptğ©2delimited-[]ğ‘˜superscriptğ’œ2\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{c},\boldsymbol{p}^{(1)}}[k\mathcal{A}^{(1)}]\neq% kâ¢ğ’œ(q)={kâ¢ğš|ğšâˆˆğ’œ(q)}ğ‘˜superscriptğ’œğ‘conditional-setğ‘˜ğšğšsuperscriptğ’œğ‘k\mathcal{A}^{(q)}=\{k\bm{a}~{}|~{}\bm{a}\in\mathcal{A}^{(q)}\}italic_k caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { italic_k bold_italic_a | bold_italic_a âˆˆ caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }.

The condition in AssumptionÂ 1 is a geometric way to characterize the difference between â„™ğ’„,ğ’‘(1)subscriptâ„™ğ’„superscriptğ’‘1\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{c},\boldsymbol{p}^{(1)}}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c , bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â„™ğ’„,ğ’‘(2)subscriptâ„™ğ’„superscriptğ’‘2\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{c},\boldsymbol{p}^{(2)}}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c , bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€”if the joint distributions have different measures for all possible â€œstripesâ€, each being a direct sum of a subspace and a convex hull (see Fig.Â 2), then â„™ğ’„,ğ’‘(1)subscriptâ„™ğ’„superscriptğ’‘1\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{c},\boldsymbol{p}^{(1)}}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c , bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â„™ğ’„,ğ’‘(2\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{c},\boldsymbol{p}^{(2}}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c , bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT must be very different. Note that the difference is contributed by the modality-specific term ğ’‘(q)superscriptğ’‘ğ‘\boldsymbol{p}^{(q)}bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and thus we call this condition â€œmodality variabilityâ€. Modality variability is similar to the â€œdomain variablityâ€ used in [32, 39]â€”both characterize the discrepancy of the joint probabilities â„™ğ’„,ğ’‘(1)subscriptâ„™ğ’„superscriptğ’‘1\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{c},\boldsymbol{p}^{(1)}}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c , bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â„™ğ’„,ğ’‘(2\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{c},\boldsymbol{p}^{(2}}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c , bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, there are key differences: The domain variability was defined in a unified latent domain over arbitrary sets ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A, which could be stringent. Instead, we use the fact that (6) relies on linear operations to construct ğ’œ(q)superscriptğ’œğ‘\mathcal{A}^{(q)}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which makes the condition defined over a much smaller class of setsâ€”thereby largely relaxing the requirements. Restricting ğ’œ(q)superscriptğ’œğ‘\mathcal{A}^{(q)}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to be stripes also makes the modality variability condition much more relaxed compared to the domain variability condition.

We show the following:

Theorem 1.

Under AssumptionÂ 1 and the generative model in (1), denote any solution of (6) as ğ^(q)superscript^ğğ‘\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT q=1,2ğ‘12q=1,2italic_q = 1 , 2. Then, if the mixing matrices ğ€(q)superscriptğ€ğ‘\boldsymbol{A}^{(q)}bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are full column ranks and ğ”¼[ğœğœâŠ¤])\mathbb{E}[\bm{c}\bm{c}^{\!\top\!}])roman_ğ”¼ [ bold_italic_c bold_italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ) is full rank, we have ğ^(q)â¢ğ±(q)=ğš¯(q)â¢ğœsuperscript^ğğ‘superscriptğ±ğ‘superscriptğš¯ğ‘ğœ\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}^{(q)}\bm{c}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c. In addition, assume that either of the following is satisfied:

  • (a)

    The individual elements of the content components are statistically independent and non-Gaussian. In addition, ciâ‰ (ğ–½)kâ¢cj,âˆ€iâ‰ j,âˆ€kâˆˆâ„formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ–½subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘—formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘–ğ‘—for-allğ‘˜â„c_{i}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle({\sf d})}}{{\neq}}kc_{j},\forall i\neq j,\forall k% \in\mathbb{R}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG â‰  end_ARG start_ARG ( sansserif_d ) end_ARG end_RELOP italic_k italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_i â‰  italic_j , âˆ€ italic_k âˆˆ roman_â„ and ciâ‰ (ğ–½)âˆ’ci,âˆ€isuperscriptğ–½subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–for-allğ‘–c_{i}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle({\sf d})}}{{\neq}}-c_{i},\forall iitalic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG â‰  end_ARG start_ARG ( sansserif_d ) end_ARG end_RELOP - italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_i, i.e., the marginal distributions of the content elements cannot be matched with each other by mere scaling.

  • (b)

    The support of â„™ğ’„subscriptâ„™ğ’„\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{c}}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, denoted by ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C, is a hyper-rectangle, i.e., ğ’=[âˆ’a1,a1]Ã—â‹¯Ã—[âˆ’adC,adC]ğ’subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘1â‹¯subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘‘C\mathcal{C}=[-a_{1},a_{1}]\times\dots\times[-a_{d_{\rm C}},a_{d_{\rm C}}]caligraphic_C = [ - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] Ã— â‹¯ Ã— [ - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]. Further, suppose that ciâ‰ (ğ–½)kâ¢cj,âˆ€iâ‰ j,âˆ€kâˆˆâ„formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ–½subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘—formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘–ğ‘—for-allğ‘˜â„c_{i}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle({\sf d})}}{{\neq}}kc_{j},\forall i\neq j,\forall k% \in\mathbb{R}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG â‰  end_ARG start_ARG ( sansserif_d ) end_ARG end_RELOP italic_k italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_i â‰  italic_j , âˆ€ italic_k âˆˆ roman_â„ and ciâ‰ (ğ–½)âˆ’ci,âˆ€isuperscriptğ–½subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–for-allğ‘–c_{i}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle({\sf d})}}{{\neq}}-c_{i},\forall iitalic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG â‰  end_ARG start_ARG ( sansserif_d ) end_ARG end_RELOP - italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_i.

Then, we have ğ^(q)â¢ğ±(q)=ğš¯â¢ğœ,superscript^ğğ‘superscriptğ±ğ‘ğš¯ğœ\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}\bm{c},over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ bold_italic_c , i.e., ğš¯(q)=ğš¯superscriptğš¯ğ‘ğš¯\bm{\Theta}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ for all q=1,2ğ‘12q=1,2italic_q = 1 , 2, where ğš¯(q)superscriptğš¯ğ‘\bm{\Theta}^{(q)}bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

In TheoremÂ 1, AssumptionÂ 1 is used to guarantee ğ‘¸^(q)â¢ğ’™(q)=ğš¯(q)â¢ğ’„superscript^ğ‘¸ğ‘superscriptğ’™ğ‘superscriptğš¯ğ‘ğ’„\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}^{(q)}\bm{c}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c and either of conditions (a) or (b) is used to make sure ğš¯(1)=ğš¯(2)superscriptğš¯1superscriptğš¯2\bm{\Theta}^{(1)}=\bm{\Theta}^{(2)}bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that both (a) and (b) are milder than those in [8] (cf. TheoremÂ 5), where the element-wise statistical independence of ğ’›(q)superscriptğ’›ğ‘\boldsymbol{z}^{(q)}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT was relied on to find shared representation of ğ’™(1)superscriptğ’™1\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ’™(2)superscriptğ’™2\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The proof is in AppendixÂ B.

Numerical Validation. In Fig.Â 3, the top and bottom rows validate TheoremÂ 1 under the assumptions in (a) and (b), respectively. In the top row, we set ğ’„âˆˆâ„2ğ’„superscriptâ„2\bm{c}\in\mathbb{R}^{2}bold_italic_c âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where c1subscriptğ‘1c_{1}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is sampled from Gaussian mixtures with three components and c2subscriptğ‘2c_{2}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is sampled from a Gamma distribution (and c1âŸ‚âŸ‚c2c_{1}\perp\!\!\!\perp c_{2}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ‚ âŸ‚ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). We set p(1)superscriptğ‘1p^{(1)}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and p(2)superscriptğ‘2p^{(2)}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as one-dimensional Laplacian and uniform distributions. In the bottom row, the dimensions of ğ’„ğ’„\bm{c}bold_italic_c and ğ’‘(q)superscriptğ’‘ğ‘\bm{p}^{(q)}bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for q=1,2ğ‘12q=1,2italic_q = 1 , 2 are unchanged, but their distributions are replaced in order to satisfy conditions in (b) (see details in AppendixÂ F). One can see that clearly ğ’„^(q)=ğš¯â¢ğ’„superscript^ğ’„ğ‘ğš¯ğ’„\widehat{\bm{c}}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}\bm{c}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ bold_italic_c; i.e., the learned ğ’„^(q)superscript^ğ’„ğ‘\widehat{\bm{c}}^{(q)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for q=1,2ğ‘12q=1,2italic_q = 1 , 2 are identically rotated and scaled versions of ğ’„ğ’„\bm{c}bold_italic_c.

A remark is that our framework still allows to identify individual cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s as in [8].

Corollary 1.

Under the conditions in TheoremÂ 1 (a), Assume that at most one cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for iâˆˆ[dC]ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‘Ci\in[d_{\rm C}]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] is Gaussian. Then, the components of ğœğœ\bm{c}bold_italic_c are identifiable up to permutation and scaling ambiguities by applying ICA to ğœ^(q)=ğ^(q)â¢ğ±(q)superscript^ğœğ‘superscript^ğğ‘superscriptğ±ğ‘\widehat{\bm{c}}^{(q)}=\widehat{\bm{Q}}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for either q=1ğ‘1q=1italic_q = 1 or q=2ğ‘2q=2italic_q = 2.

The corollary means that to identify individual cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, using our formulation still enjoys much milder conditions relative to [8]. Specifically, our condition only specifies the independence among elements of ğ’„ğ’„\boldsymbol{c}bold_italic_c, but the condition in [8] needs that all the elements in ğ’›(q)=[ğ’„âŠ¤,(ğ’‘(q))âŠ¤]âŠ¤superscriptğ’›ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptğ’„topsuperscriptsuperscriptğ’‘ğ‘toptop\bm{z}^{(q)}=[\bm{c}^{\!\top\!},(\bm{p}^{(q)})^{\!\top\!}]^{\!\top\!}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ bold_italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are independent.

4 Enhanced Identifiability via Structural Constraints

TheoremÂ 1 was well-supported by the synthetic data experiments. However, our experiments found that the learning criterion (6) often struggles to produce sensible results in some applications. Our conjecture is that the Assumptions in TheoremÂ 1 (a) and (b) might not have been satisfied by the real data under our tests. Although they are not necessary conditions for identifiability, these conditions do indicate that the requirements to guarantee identifiability of unaligned SCA using (6) are nontrivial to meet. In this section, we explore a couple of structural constraints arising from side information in applications to remove the need for the relatively stringent assumptions on ğ’„ğ’„\bm{c}bold_italic_c.

Homogeneous Domains. The first structural constraint that we consider is ğ‘¨(q)=ğ‘¨superscriptğ‘¨ğ‘ğ‘¨\boldsymbol{A}^{(q)}=\boldsymbol{A}bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_A for q=1,2ğ‘12q=1,2italic_q = 1 , 2. This model is motivated by the fact that advanced representation learning tools, e.g., self-supervised learning tools (e.g., SimCLR [40]) and foundation models (e.g., CLIP [34]), are already capable of mapping the data clusters to a shared linearly separable spaceâ€”which indicates that the representations share a subspace, i.e., ğ’™(q)â‰ˆğ‘¨â¢ğ’›(q)superscriptğ’™ğ‘ğ‘¨superscriptğ’›ğ‘\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}\approx\boldsymbol{A}\boldsymbol{z}^{(q)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ˆ bold_italic_A bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Under such circumstances, the proposed model and method can be used to further process the data by discarding the private components in the latent representation.

Here, we consider the special case of generative process in (1) where,

ğ’™(q)=ğ‘¨â¢[ğ’„âŠ¤,(ğ’‘(q))âŠ¤]âŠ¤.superscriptğ’™ğ‘ğ‘¨superscriptsuperscriptğ’„topsuperscriptsuperscriptğ’‘ğ‘toptop\displaystyle\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}=\boldsymbol{A}[\bm{c}^{\top},(\bm{p}^{(q)})^% {\top}]^{\top}.bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_A [ bold_italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (6h)

Under this model, we look for the shared components by solving (6) with a single ğ‘¸=ğ‘¸(1)=ğ‘¸(2)ğ‘¸superscriptğ‘¸1superscriptğ‘¸2\boldsymbol{Q}=\boldsymbol{Q}^{(1)}=\boldsymbol{Q}^{(2)}bold_italic_Q = bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We use the following version of the modality variability condition:

Assumption 2.

For any linear subspace ğ’«âŠ‚â„dC+dP,dP=dP(1)=dP(2)formulae-sequenceğ’«superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘‘Psubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ƒ1superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ƒ2\mathcal{P}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with dimâ¢(ğ’«)=dPdimğ’«subscriptğ‘‘P{\rm dim}(\mathcal{P})=d_{\rm P}roman_dim ( caligraphic_P ) = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ğ’«â‰ ğŸÃ—â„dPğ’«0superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘P\mathcal{P}\neq\boldsymbol{0}\times\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm P}}caligraphic_P â‰  bold_0 Ã— roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and linearly independent vectors {ğ²iâˆˆâ„dC+dP}i=1dC,q=1,2formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ²ğ‘–superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘‘Pğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘Cğ‘12\{\boldsymbol{y}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}+d_{\rm P}}\}_{i=1}^{d_{\rm C}},~{% }q=1,2{ bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_q = 1 , 2, the sets ğ’œ=convâ¢{ğŸ,ğ²1,â€¦,ğ²dC}+ğ’«,q=1,2.formulae-sequenceğ’œconv0subscriptğ²1â€¦subscriptğ²subscriptğ‘‘Cğ’«ğ‘12\mathcal{A}={\rm conv}\{\boldsymbol{0},\boldsymbol{y}_{1},\dots,\boldsymbol{y}% _{d_{\rm C}}\}+\mathcal{P},~{}q=1,2.caligraphic_A = roman_conv { bold_0 , bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } + caligraphic_P , italic_q = 1 , 2 . are such that if â„™ğœ,ğ©(q)â¢[ğ’œ]>0subscriptâ„™ğœsuperscriptğ©ğ‘delimited-[]ğ’œ0\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{c},\boldsymbol{p}^{(q)}}[\mathcal{A}]>0roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c , bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ caligraphic_A ] > 0 for q=1ğ‘1q=1italic_q = 1 or q=2ğ‘2q=2italic_q = 2, then the joint distributions â„™ğœ,ğ©(1)â¢[kâ¢ğ’œ]â‰ â„™ğœ,ğ©(2)â¢[kâ¢ğ’œ]subscriptâ„™ğœsuperscriptğ©1delimited-[]ğ‘˜ğ’œsubscriptâ„™ğœsuperscriptğ©2delimited-[]ğ‘˜ğ’œ\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{c},\boldsymbol{p}^{(1)}}[k\mathcal{A}]\neq\mathbb{P}_{% \boldsymbol{c},\boldsymbol{p}^{(2)}}[k\mathcal{A}]roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c , bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k caligraphic_A ] â‰  roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c , bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k caligraphic_A ] for some kâˆˆâ„ğ‘˜â„k\in\mathbb{R}italic_k âˆˆ roman_â„.

Theorem 2.

Consider the mixture model in (6h). Assume that rankâ¢(ğ€)=dC+dPrankğ€subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘‘P{\rm rank}(\boldsymbol{A})=d_{\rm C}+d_{\rm P}roman_rank ( bold_italic_A ) = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and rankâ¢(ğ”¼â¢[ğœâ¢ğœâŠ¤])=dCrankğ”¼delimited-[]ğœsuperscriptğœtopsubscriptğ‘‘C{\rm rank}(\mathbb{E}[\bm{c}\bm{c}^{\!\top\!}])={d_{\rm C}}roman_rank ( roman_ğ”¼ [ bold_italic_c bold_italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ) = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and that AssumptionÂ 2 holds. Denote ğ^^ğ\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG as any solution of (6) by constraining ğ=ğ(1)=ğ(2)ğsuperscriptğ1superscriptğ2\boldsymbol{Q}=\boldsymbol{Q}^{(1)}=\boldsymbol{Q}^{(2)}bold_italic_Q = bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, we have ğ^â¢ğ±(q)=ğš¯â¢ğœ^ğsuperscriptğ±ğ‘ğš¯ğœ\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}\bm{c}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ bold_italic_c.

One can see that the conditions (a) and (b) in TheoremÂ 1 are completely removed, if the structure ğ‘¨(1)=ğ‘¨(2)superscriptğ‘¨1superscriptğ‘¨2\boldsymbol{A}^{(1)}=\boldsymbol{A}^{(2)}bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is imposed. In fact, the result in TheoremÂ 2 is expected and readily seen from the proof of TheoremÂ 1, as the cause for ğš¯(1)â‰ ğš¯(2)superscriptğš¯1superscriptğš¯2\bm{\Theta}^{(1)}\neq\bm{\Theta}^{(2)}bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the use of two different ğ‘¸(q)superscriptğ‘¸ğ‘\boldsymbol{Q}^{(q)}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTâ€™s. Nonetheless, this simple variation will prove useful in a series of real-data experiments.

The Weakly Supervised Case. Another way to add structural constraints is to use available auxiliary information. For example, some datasets have weak annotations and selected pairs; see, e.g., [41, 42].

Assumption 3 (Weak Supervision).

There exist a set of available aligned samples (ğ±â„“(1),ğ±â„“(2))superscriptsubscriptğ±â„“1superscriptsubscriptğ±â„“2(\boldsymbol{x}_{\ell}^{(1)},\boldsymbol{x}_{\ell}^{(2)})( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for â„“âˆˆâ„’â„“â„’\ell\in{\cal L}roman_â„“ âˆˆ caligraphic_L such that ğ±â„“(q)=ğ€(q)â¢ğ³â„“(q),ğ³â„“(q)=[ğœâ„“âŠ¤,(ğ©â„“(q))âŠ¤]âŠ¤;formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ±â„“ğ‘superscriptğ€ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ³â„“ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ³â„“ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœâ„“topsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ©â„“ğ‘toptop\boldsymbol{x}_{\ell}^{(q)}=\boldsymbol{A}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{z}_{\ell}^{(q)},~{% }\boldsymbol{z}_{\ell}^{(q)}=[\bm{c}_{\ell}^{\!\top\!},(\bm{p}_{\ell}^{(q)})^{% {\!\top\!}}]^{\!\top\!};bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( bold_italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; i.e., (ğ±â„“(1),ğ±â„“(2))superscriptsubscriptğ±â„“1superscriptsubscriptğ±â„“2(\boldsymbol{x}_{\ell}^{(1)},\boldsymbol{x}_{\ell}^{(2)})( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) share the same ğœâ„“subscriptğœâ„“\bm{c}_{\ell}bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The condition can be added into our formulation in (6) as a constraint, i.e.,

ğ‘¸(1)â¢ğ’™â„“(1)=ğ‘¸(2)â¢ğ’™â„“(2),âˆ€â„“âˆˆâ„’.formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘¸1subscriptsuperscriptğ’™1â„“superscriptğ‘¸2subscriptsuperscriptğ’™2â„“for-allâ„“â„’\displaystyle\boldsymbol{Q}^{(1)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}_{\ell}=\boldsymbol{Q}^{(% 2)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}_{\ell},~{}\forall\ell\in{\cal L}.bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ€ roman_â„“ âˆˆ caligraphic_L . (6i)

In the next theorem, we show that the incorporation of aligned samples helps relax conditions (a) and (b) in TheoremÂ 1:

Theorem 3.

Assume that Assumption 1 is satisfied, that |â„’|â‰¥dCâ„’subscriptğ‘‘C|{\mathcal{L}}|\geq d_{\rm C}| caligraphic_L | â‰¥ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT paired samples (ğ±â„“(1),ğ±â„“(2))superscriptsubscriptğ±â„“1superscriptsubscriptğ±â„“2(\boldsymbol{x}_{\ell}^{(1)},\boldsymbol{x}_{\ell}^{(2)})( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) are available, that ğ€(q)superscriptğ€ğ‘\bm{A}^{(q)}bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for q=1,2ğ‘12q=1,2italic_q = 1 , 2 have full column rank, and that â„™ğœsubscriptâ„™ğœ\mathbb{P}_{\bm{c}}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is absolutely continuous. Denote (ğ^(1),ğ^(2))superscript^ğ1superscript^ğ2(\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(1)},\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(2)})( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) as any optimal solution of (6) under the constraint (6i). Then, we have ğ^(q)â¢ğ±(q)=ğš¯â¢ğœsuperscript^ğğ‘superscriptğ±ğ‘ğš¯ğœ\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}\bm{c}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ bold_italic_c.

The proof and synthetic data validation can be found in Appendices D and Â F, respectively. Note that to realize (6i), one only needs to add a regularization term Î²â¢âˆ‘â„“âˆˆâ„’â€–ğ‘¸(1)â¢ğ’™â„“(1)âˆ’ğ‘¸(2)â¢ğ’™â„“(2)â€–22ğ›½subscriptâ„“â„’superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¸1subscriptsuperscriptğ’™1â„“superscriptğ‘¸2subscriptsuperscriptğ’™2â„“22\beta\sum_{\ell\in{\cal L}}\|\boldsymbol{Q}^{(1)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}_{\ell}-% \boldsymbol{Q}^{(2)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}_{\ell}\|_{2}^{2}italic_Î² âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ âˆˆ caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to the loss in (6g), where Î²â‰¥0ğ›½0\beta\geq 0italic_Î² â‰¥ 0 is a tunable parameter. The overall loss is still differentiable and thus can be easily handled by gradient based approaches.

A remark is that our weakly supervised formulation can use as few as dCsubscriptğ‘‘Cd_{\rm C}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT pairs of (ğ’™â„“(1),ğ’™â„“(2))superscriptsubscriptğ’™â„“1superscriptsubscriptğ’™â„“2(\boldsymbol{x}_{\ell}^{(1)},\boldsymbol{x}_{\ell}^{(2)})( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) to establish identifiability of shared component. In contrast, CCA requires at least dC+dP(1)+dP(2)subscriptğ‘‘Csuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‘P1superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘P2d_{\rm C}+d_{\rm P}^{(1)}+d_{\rm P}^{(2)}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT pairs to attain the same identifiability (cf. Appendix.Â E.1).

Private Component Identifiability. Although our focus is shared component identification, we show that private components are also identifiable with additional assumptions; see AppendixÂ H.

5 Related Works

Identifiability of Component Analysis under Linear Mixture Models. Various component analysis models were studied in the past several decades, e.g., principal component analysis [43], independent component analysis [33], sparse component analysis [12, 10], bounded component analysis [13], simplex component analysis [44], and polytopic component analysis [14]â€”motivated by their applications in dimensionality reduction, representation learning, and latent variable identification (see, e.g., topic mining [45], hyperspectral unmixing [44], audio/speech separation [33] and community detection [46]). The classical component analysis tools mostly study a single modality. The identifiability results under these models are well developed and documented.

Identifiability of Shared Components from Aligned Modalities. Modeling multimodal data as two or more linear/nonlinear mixtures of latent components was considered in CCA-related works [1, 2, 15, 19], independent vector analysis (IVA) works [17, 18], multiview ICA works [16, 47], and SSL works [6, 5, 7, 48]. Partitioning the latent components into shared and private blocks was considered in [1, 2, 4, 5, 7, 48]. Shared component identifiability was established at the block level (see, e.g., [1, 2, 5]) and the individual component level (e.g., [47]) in these works. Nonetheless, they all rely on completely paired/aligned cross-modality samples, which we do not use in this work.

Distribution Matching and Unaligned Multimodal Analysis. Using distribution matching in unaligned multimodal data analytics for different purpose also has a long history; see applications in image-to-image translation [49], domain adaptation [50], cross-platform image super-resolution [51], and cross-domain information retrieval [21]. The recent works [52] and [53] pointed out the identifiability challenge and the existence of density-preserving transforms. The works in [28, 29] started studying the uniqueness issues in distribution matching. However, the latent mixture models were not studied in this line of work.

Identifiability of Unaligned SCA. The works in [39, 32] investigated the shared component identifiability when the multimodal data are nonlinear mixtures of content and style (which are shared and private components, respectively) under the same mixing system. Hence, our identical linear mixing case in TheoremÂ 2 can be understood as a special case of theirs. But their analysis relies on the assumption that all the latent components are statistically independent, which is much stronger than our conditions in TheoremÂ 2. Their results also require that there are a large amount of modalities available. But our proof works for just two modalities. The most related work is [8], which uses the model in (1) in the context of multi-view causal graph learning. As discussed before, their assumptions on the latent components are much stronger than ours (see CorollaryÂ 1 and AppendixÂ E.2).

6 Numerical Validation

More Synthetic-Data Validation. See Appendix F for more simulations. In the sequel, we apply the proposed methods onto real-data tasks to show usefulness of the models and algorithms.

Application (i) - Domain Adaptation. We first test the proposed methods over a number of domain adaptation (DA) tasks. In DA, we have the source domain data {ğ’™(1)}superscriptğ’™1\{\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}\}{ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } and the target domain {ğ’™(2)}superscriptğ’™2\{\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}\}{ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }, respectively. Only the source domain data have labels and the two domains are unaligned. We hope to use our method to find shared representations of source and target, and thus the classifier trained using source data can also work well on the target data.

Dataset: We use two standard benchmarks of DA, i.e., Office-31 [54] and Office-Home [55]. The Office-31 dataset has 4652 images and 31 categories from three domains, namely, Amazon images (A), Webcam images (W) and DSLR images (D). The Office-Home dataset contains 15,500 images with 65 object classes from four domains, i.e., Artistic images (Ar), Clip art images (Cl), Product images (Pr), and Real-world images (Rw).

Setup: We first test the homogeneous domain model in Sec.Â 4. The images are pre-processed by the pretrained CLIP model [34] that uses ViT-L/14 transformer architecture. The embedded images are of sizes d(q)=768,q=1,2formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘‘ğ‘768ğ‘12d^{(q)}=768,~{}q=1,2italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 768 , italic_q = 1 , 2. We set dC=256subscriptğ‘‘C256d_{\rm C}=256italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 256 for Office-31 and dC=512subscriptğ‘‘C512d_{\rm C}=512italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 512 for Office-Home. More detailed settings are in AppendixÂ G.

Baselines and Training Setup: The baselines are representative DA methods, namely, DANN [25], ADDA[56], DAN[24], JAN[50] ,CDAN[57], MDD[58], and MCC[59]. All the baselines integrate deep neural networks as their shared representation learner and the classifier trained over the source data (see AppendixÂ G.2 for their configurations). We also use CLIP as an extra baseline as it learns informative and transferable features from excessively large datasets according to empirical studies. We follow the training strategies adopted by the baselines [24, 25, 57, 58] to learn a classifier jointly with the feature extractors. This strategy arguably regularizes towards more classification-friendly geometry of the shared features. Therefore we append a cross-entropy (CE) based classifier training module to our loss in (6g) that learns our feature extractor ğ‘¸ğ‘¸\bm{Q}bold_italic_Q. More details are in AppendixÂ G.2.

Metric: The evaluation metric is the classification accuracy in the target domain {ğ’™(2)}superscriptğ’™2\{\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}\}{ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }. The classifier is trained with the projected source domain ğ‘¸^â¢ğ’™(1)^ğ‘¸superscriptğ’™1\widehat{\bm{Q}}\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the associated labels.

Result: Table 1 and Table 2 show the results on Office-31 and Office-Home, respectively. The results are averaged over 5 runs. One can observe that the proposed method and the CLIP model offers the best and the second best performance in most of the tasks. This shows that, as a foundation model, CLIP can already unify the embeddings of the source and target domains in a reasonable extent. In addition, Our model and algorithm are useful as a relatively simple post-processing of CLIPâ€”Our method always improves upon CLIP; in some tasks (e.g.,â€œWâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’Aâ€, â€œArâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’CIâ€, â€œPrâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’Arâ€ and â€œPrâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’CIâ€), more than 4% accuracy gains can be obtained by using the proposed method.

Application (ii) - Single Cell Sequence Analysis. In biomedical research, it is desired to fuse measurements from multiple sensorial modalities of the same cells, in order to have better characterizations of the cells. However, obtaining multimodal data of the same cells simultaneously is almost impossible, due to the sensing limitations. Therefore, many methods are proposed in the literature for aligning unpaired multi-modal single cell data [27, 60, 61]. We focus on the following two modalities of single-cell data [62]: (1) the RNA sequences {ğ’™(1)}superscriptğ’™1\{\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}\}{ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } and (2) the ATAC sequences {ğ’™(2)}superscriptğ’™2\{\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}\}{ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }.

Dataset: We use human lung adenocarcinoma A549 cells data from [62]. The dataset contains 1,874 samples of RNA sequences {ğ’™(1)}superscriptğ’™1\{\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}\}{ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } and ATAC sequences {ğ’™(2)}superscriptğ’™2\{\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}\}{ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }. Each data set is split into 1534 training samples and 340 testing samples as in [27]. The data have labeled associations between the two domainsâ€”part of which will be used to test our weakly supervised formulation. For this experiment, features of RNA sequence and the ATAC sequence have dimensions of d(1)=815superscriptğ‘‘1815d^{(1)}=815italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 815 and d(2)=2613superscriptğ‘‘22613d^{(2)}=2613italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2613, respectively. We set dC=256subscriptğ‘‘C256d_{\rm C}=256italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 256. We use our weakly supervised formulation as shown in (6i). We uniformly sampled a set of indices from the training set to serve as â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L.

Baseline and Metric: We use weakly supervised algorithm, namely, cross-modal autoencoder (CM-AE) work in [27], as a baseline, which also learns the shared representation between unaligned RNA and ATAC sequences. We use the Kğ¾Kitalic_K-nearest neighbor (kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN) accuracy to evaluate the performance as suggested in [27].

Result:

The plot in Fig.Â 4 shows the kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN accuracy of the methods on the test set. Results show the mean and standard deviation over 10 runs, each having a different random initialization. For the proposed method, we vary the number of available paired samples from 00 (cf. Theorem 1) to dC=256subscriptğ‘‘C256d_{\rm C}=256italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 256 (cf. Theorem 3). Note that the baseline uses more (i.e., 256256256256 and 770770770770) paired samples. It also needs additional class labels, i.e., yi(q)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘y_{i}^{(q)}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for the iğ‘–iitalic_ith sample ğ’™i(q)subscriptsuperscriptğ’™ğ‘ğ‘–\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}_{i}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Here, yi(q)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘y_{i}^{(q)}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT represents the number of hours (00, 1111 or 3333) of cell treatment [62, 27]. The proposed method without any supervision (i.e., 00 paired samples) already exhibits around 3 times greater kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN accuracy compared to the baseline for all kğ‘˜kitalic_k. Moreover, including just one paired sample boosts the kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN accuracy of the proposed method to around 5 times higher than the baseline for all kğ‘˜kitalic_k. Finally, one can observe a steadily increasing kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN accuracy with respect to the number of available paired samples. This corroborates with our Theorem 3.

Application (iii) - Multi-lingual Information Retrieval. We also evaluated our method on a word embedding association problem from the natural language processing literature [21, 20]. In this task, the goal is to associate unaligned word embeddings across different languages. The details are in AppendixÂ G.1 due to page limitations.

7 Conclusion

In this work, we considered the problem of identifying shared components from unaligned multi-domain mixtures. We proposed a learning loss that matches the distributions of linearly transformed data. Based on this loss, we came up with a suite of sufficient conditions to ensure the identifiability of shared components. Furthermore, we proposed modified models and losses that enjoy more relaxed conditions for shared component identifiability. This was achieved via introducing structural constraints, namely, the homogeneity of the mixing systems and the existence of weak supervision. Our theoretical claims were validated with both synthetic and real-world data, demonstrating soundness of the theorems and usefulness of the models/algorithms.

Limitations. First, our conditions for shared component identification are sufficient. The necessary conditions are not underpinned, but necessary conditions assist understanding the limitations of the models and algorithms. Second, our methods were developed under the linear mixture model, which has limited expressiveness, and thus often requires pre-processing to approximately meet the model specification. We expect that results with similar flavors to be derived for nonlinear models in the future. Third, the results were derived under an unlimited data assumption. It would be interesting have a finite sample analysis.

Appendix B Proof of TheoremÂ 1

We restate the theorem here: {mdframed}[backgroundcolor=gray!10,topline=false, rightline=false, leftline=false, bottomline=false] TheoremÂ 1 Under AssumptionÂ 1 and the generative model in (1), denote any solution of (6) as ğ‘¸^(q)superscript^ğ‘¸ğ‘\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT q=1,2ğ‘12q=1,2italic_q = 1 , 2. B.1 Linearly transformed content identification

Let us define

ğ‘¯(q)=ğ‘¸(q)â¢ğ‘¨(q)âˆˆâ„dCÃ—(dC+dP(q)).superscriptğ‘¯ğ‘superscriptğ‘¸ğ‘superscriptğ‘¨ğ‘superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘‘Csuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‘Pğ‘\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}=\boldsymbol{Q}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{A}^{(q)}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_% {\rm C}\times(d_{\rm C}+d_{\rm P}^{(q)})}.bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— ( italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

We want to show that

Nullâ¢(ğ‘¯(q))=ğŸÃ—â„dP(q),Nullsuperscriptğ‘¯ğ‘0superscriptâ„superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘Pğ‘\displaystyle{\rm Null}(\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)})=\boldsymbol{0}\times\mathbb{R}^{% d_{\rm P}^{(q)}},roman_Null ( bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = bold_0 Ã— roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (6bi)

since this will imply that that ğ‘¯(q)superscriptğ‘¯ğ‘\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT does not depend upon the style component. Combined with the fact that rankâ¢(ğ‘¯(q))=dCranksuperscriptğ‘¯ğ‘subscriptğ‘‘C{\rm rank}(\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)})=d_{\rm C}roman_rank ( bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, this will imply that ğ‘¯(q)superscriptğ‘¯ğ‘\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an invertible function of the content component. To that end, consider the following line of arguments.

Since the objective in (6) matches the distribution for latent random variables ğ’„^(1)=ğ‘¸(1)â¢ğ’™(1)superscript^ğ’„1superscriptğ‘¸1superscriptğ’™1\widehat{\boldsymbol{c}}^{(1)}=\boldsymbol{Q}^{(1)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ’„^(2)=ğ‘¸(2)â¢ğ’™(2)superscript^ğ’„2superscriptğ‘¸2superscriptğ’™2\widehat{\boldsymbol{c}}^{(2)}=\boldsymbol{Q}^{(2)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the following holds for any â„›câŠ†â„dC,âˆ€kâˆˆâ„formulae-sequencesubscriptâ„›ğ‘superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘Cfor-allğ‘˜â„\mathcal{R}_{c}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}},\forall k\in\mathbb{R}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_k âˆˆ roman_â„,

â„™c^(1)â¢[kâ¢â„›c]subscriptâ„™superscript^ğ‘1delimited-[]ğ‘˜subscriptâ„›ğ‘\displaystyle\mathbb{P}_{\widehat{c}^{(1)}}[k\mathcal{R}_{c}]roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] =â„™c^(2)â¢[kâ¢â„›c],absentsubscriptâ„™superscript^ğ‘2delimited-[]ğ‘˜subscriptâ„›ğ‘\displaystyle=\mathbb{P}_{\widehat{c}^{(2)}}[k\mathcal{R}_{c}],= roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ,
â‡”(a)â„™ğ’›(1)â¢[ğ‘¯PreImg(1)â¢(kâ¢â„›c)]superscriptiffğ‘absentsubscriptâ„™superscriptğ’›1delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¯1PreImgğ‘˜subscriptâ„›ğ‘\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(a)}}{{\iff}}\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{z}^{(% 1)}}[\boldsymbol{H}^{(1)}_{\rm PreImg}(k\mathcal{R}_{c})]start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG â‡” end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_a ) end_ARG end_RELOP roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_PreImg end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] =â„™ğ’›(2)â¢[ğ‘¯PreImg(2)â¢(kâ¢â„›c)]absentsubscriptâ„™superscriptğ’›2delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¯2PreImgğ‘˜subscriptâ„›ğ‘\displaystyle=\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{z}^{(2)}}[\boldsymbol{H}^{(2)}_{\rm PreImg% }(k\mathcal{R}_{c})]= roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_PreImg end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] (6bj)
â‡”(b)â„™ğ’›(1)â¢[kâ¢ğ‘¯PreImg(1)â¢(â„›c)]superscriptiffğ‘absentsubscriptâ„™superscriptğ’›1delimited-[]ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¯1PreImgsubscriptâ„›ğ‘\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(b)}}{{\iff}}\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{z}^{(% 1)}}[k\boldsymbol{H}^{(1)}_{\rm PreImg}(\mathcal{R}_{c})]start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG â‡” end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_b ) end_ARG end_RELOP roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_PreImg end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] =â„™ğ’›(2)â¢[kâ¢ğ‘¯PreImg(2)â¢(â„›c)],absentsubscriptâ„™superscriptğ’›2delimited-[]ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¯2PreImgsubscriptâ„›ğ‘\displaystyle=\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{z}^{(2)}}[k\boldsymbol{H}^{(2)}_{\rm PreImg% }(\mathcal{R}_{c})],= roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_PreImg end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ,

For reasons that will be clear later, we hope to show that

To that end, observe that for any ğ’“âˆˆâ„›cğ’“subscriptâ„›ğ‘\boldsymbol{r}\in\mathcal{R}_{c}bold_italic_r âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we can represent ğ’“ğ’“\boldsymbol{r}bold_italic_r as,

ğ’“=1dC+1â¢âˆ‘i=1dCwiâ¢ğ’‚i,Â for someÂ â¢{wi}i=1dCâ¢s.t.âˆ‘i=1dCwiâ‰¤1,âˆ€i.formulae-sequenceğ’“1subscriptğ‘‘C1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ’‚ğ‘–Â for someÂ superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘Cğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–1for-allğ‘–\displaystyle\boldsymbol{r}=\frac{1}{d_{\rm C}+1}\sum_{i=1}^{d_{\rm C}}w_{i}% \boldsymbol{a}_{i},\text{ for some }\{w_{i}\}_{i=1}^{d_{\rm C}}~{}{s.t.}~{}% \sum_{i=1}^{d_{\rm C}}w_{i}\leq 1,~{}\forall i.bold_italic_r = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , for some { italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s . italic_t . âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 1 , âˆ€ italic_i .

ğ‘¯PreImg(q)â¢(1dC+1â¢âˆ‘i=1dCwiâ¢ğ’‚i)=1dC+1â¢âˆ‘i=1dCwiâ¢ğ’ši(q)+Nullâ¢(ğ‘¯(q))subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¯ğ‘PreImg1subscriptğ‘‘C1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ’‚ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘C1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’šğ‘–ğ‘Nullsuperscriptğ‘¯ğ‘\displaystyle\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}_{\rm PreImg}\left(\frac{1}{d_{\rm C}+1}\sum_% {i=1}^{d_{\rm C}}w_{i}\boldsymbol{a}_{i}\right)=\frac{1}{d_{\rm C}+1}\sum_{i=1% }^{d_{\rm C}}w_{i}\boldsymbol{y}_{i}^{(q)}+{\rm Null}(\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)})bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_PreImg end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Null ( bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (6bk)

We can write,
