We have that Nullâ¢(ğ‘¯(q))âŠ‚â„dC+dP(q)Nullsuperscriptğ‘¯ğ‘superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘Csuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‘Pğ‘{\rm Null}(\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)})\subset\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}+d_{\rm P}^{(q)}}roman_Null ( bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âŠ‚ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a linear subspace with dimâ¢(Nullâ¢(ğ‘¯(q)))=dP(q)dimNullsuperscriptğ‘¯ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘Pğ‘{\rm dim}({\rm Null}(\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}))=d_{\rm P}^{(q)}roman_dim ( roman_Null ( bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let ğ’œ(q)=ğ‘¯PreImg(q)â¢(â„›c)superscriptğ’œğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¯ğ‘PreImgsubscriptâ„›ğ‘\mathcal{A}^{(q)}={\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}_{\rm PreImg}(\mathcal{R}_{c})}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_PreImg end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Note that â„™ğ’›(1)â¢[kâ¢ğ’œ(1)]=â„™ğ’›(2)â¢[kâ¢ğ’œ(2)],âˆ€kâˆˆâ„formulae-sequencesubscriptâ„™superscriptğ’›1delimited-[]ğ‘˜superscriptğ’œ1subscriptâ„™superscriptğ’›2delimited-[]ğ‘˜superscriptğ’œ2for-allğ‘˜â„\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{z}^{(1)}}[k\mathcal{A}^{(1)}]=\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{% z}^{(2)}}[k\mathcal{A}^{(2)}],\forall k\in\mathbb{R}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] , âˆ€ italic_k âˆˆ roman_â„ (from (6bj), and â„™ğ’›(q)â¢[ğ’œ(q)]>0subscriptâ„™superscriptğ’›ğ‘delimited-[]superscriptğ’œğ‘0\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{z}^{(q)}}[\mathcal{A}^{(q)}]>0roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] > 0 (by the construction of â„›csubscriptâ„›ğ‘\mathcal{R}_{c}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Further, the set ğ’œ(q)superscriptğ’œğ‘\mathcal{A}^{(q)}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is of the form

convâ¢{ğŸ,ğ’š1(q),â€¦,ğ’šdC(q)}+ğ’«(q),conv0superscriptsubscriptğ’š1ğ‘â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ’šsubscriptğ‘‘Cğ‘superscriptğ’«ğ‘{\rm conv}\{\boldsymbol{0},\boldsymbol{y}_{1}^{(q)},\dots,\boldsymbol{y}_{d_{% \rm C}}^{(q)}\}+\mathcal{P}^{(q)},roman_conv { bold_0 , bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ , bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } + caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

because Nullâ¢(ğ‘¯(q))Nullsuperscriptğ‘¯ğ‘{\rm Null}(\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)})roman_Null ( bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is a subspace of dimension dP(q)superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘Pğ‘d_{\rm P}^{(q)}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, hence it satisfies the definition of ğ’«(q)superscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}^{(q)}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Hence, Assumption 1 implies that

Nullâ¢(ğ‘¯(q))=ğŸÃ—â„dP(q).Nullsuperscriptğ‘¯ğ‘0superscriptâ„superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘Pğ‘{\rm Null}(\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)})=\boldsymbol{0}\times\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm P}^{(q% )}}.roman_Null ( bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = bold_0 Ã— roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Denoting the Nğ‘Nitalic_Nth to Mğ‘€Mitalic_Mth columns of ğ‘¯(q)superscriptğ‘¯ğ‘\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by ğ‘¯(q)(N:M)\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}(N:M)bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_N : italic_M ), the above is equivalent to saying

ğ‘¯(q)(dğ‘ª+1:dğ‘ª+dğ‘·(q))=0.\displaystyle\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}(d_{\bm{C}}+1:d_{\bm{C}}+d_{\bm{P}}^{(q)})=0.bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 : italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0 . (6bm)

Denote,

ğš¯(q)=ğ‘¯(q)(1:dğ‘ª)âˆ€q=1,2.\bm{\Theta}^{(q)}=\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}(1:d_{\bm{C}})~{}\forall~{}q=1,2.bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 : italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ€ italic_q = 1 , 2 .

Then, we can write,

ğ‘¸(q)â¢ğ’™(q)=ğš¯(q)â¢ğ’„,âˆ€q=1,2.formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘superscriptğ’™ğ‘superscriptğš¯ğ‘ğ’„for-allğ‘12\displaystyle\boldsymbol{Q}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}^{(q)}\bm{c},% ~{}\forall~{}q=1,2.bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c , âˆ€ italic_q = 1 , 2 . (6bn)

Next, we use Assumption (a) or (b) to show that ğš¯(1)=ğš¯(2)=ğš¯superscriptğš¯1superscriptğš¯2ğš¯\bm{\Theta}^{(1)}=\bm{\Theta}^{(2)}=\bm{\Theta}bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜. To that end, note that the distribution matching constraint implies that

ğš¯(1)â¢ğ’„â¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢ğš¯(2)â¢ğ’„superscriptğš¯1ğ’„\xlongequalğ–½superscriptğš¯2ğ’„\displaystyle\bm{\Theta}^{(1)}\boldsymbol{c}\xlongequal{({\sf d})}\bm{\Theta}^% {(2)}\boldsymbol{c}bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c ( sansserif_d ) bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c
âŸ¹\displaystyle\impliesâŸ¹ ğ’„â¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢(ğš¯(1))âˆ’1â¢ğš¯(2)â¢ğ’„.ğ’„\xlongequalğ–½superscriptsuperscriptğš¯11superscriptğš¯2ğ’„\displaystyle\boldsymbol{c}\xlongequal{({\sf d})}(\bm{\Theta}^{(1)})^{-1}\bm{% \Theta}^{(2)}\boldsymbol{c}.bold_italic_c ( sansserif_d ) ( bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c .

Hence ğ‘´=(ğš¯(1))âˆ’1â¢ğš¯(2)ğ‘´superscriptsuperscriptğš¯11superscriptğš¯2\boldsymbol{M}=(\bm{\Theta}^{(1)})^{-1}\bm{\Theta}^{(2)}bold_italic_M = ( bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an invertible matrix such that ğ’„â¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢ğ‘´â¢ğ’„ğ’„\xlongequalğ–½ğ‘´ğ’„\boldsymbol{c}\xlongequal{({\sf d})}\boldsymbol{M}\boldsymbol{c}bold_italic_c ( sansserif_d ) bold_italic_M bold_italic_c. However, in the following, we will show that if either Assumption (a) or (b) is satisfied, then ğ‘´=ğ‘°ğ‘´ğ‘°\boldsymbol{M}=\bm{I}bold_italic_M = bold_italic_I, and thus ğš¯(1)=ğš¯(2)superscriptğš¯1superscriptğš¯2\bm{\Theta}^{(1)}=\bm{\Theta}^{(2)}bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

B.2 Considering Assumption (a)

We want to show that when Assumption (a) is satisfied, if ğ‘´â¢ğ’„â¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢ğ’„ğ‘´ğ’„\xlongequalğ–½ğ’„\boldsymbol{M}\boldsymbol{c}\xlongequal{({\sf d})}\boldsymbol{c}bold_italic_M bold_italic_c ( sansserif_d ) bold_italic_c for any invertible ğ‘´ğ‘´\boldsymbol{M}bold_italic_M, then ğ‘´=ğ‘°ğ‘´ğ‘°\boldsymbol{M}=\bm{I}bold_italic_M = bold_italic_I.

Note that ğ‘´â¢ğ’„=[ğ’1â¢â€¦â¢ğ’dC]â¢[c1â‹®cdC]ğ‘´ğ’„delimited-[]subscriptğ’1â€¦subscriptğ’subscriptğ‘‘Cmatrixsubscriptğ‘1â‹®subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘‘C\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c}=[\boldsymbol{m}_{1}\ldots\boldsymbol{m}_{d_{\rm C}}]% \begin{bmatrix}c_{1}\\ \vdots\\ c_{d_{\rm C}}\end{bmatrix}bold_italic_M bold_italic_c = [ bold_italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â€¦ bold_italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL â‹® end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ]. By Assumption (a), we have that the components of content are statistically independent ciâŸ‚âŸ‚cj,iâ‰ jc_{i}\perp\!\!\!\perp c_{j},~{}i\neq jitalic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ‚ âŸ‚ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i â‰  italic_j , non-Gaussian, and has non-zero kurtosis. Then, according to cumulant multilinearity and additivity properties, the fourth order cumulant tensor Cumâ¢(ğ‘´â¢ğ’„)Cumğ‘´ğ’„{\rm Cum}(\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c})roman_Cum ( bold_italic_M bold_italic_c ) of ğ‘´â¢ğ’„ğ‘´ğ’„\boldsymbol{M}\boldsymbol{c}bold_italic_M bold_italic_c has the following unique decomposition [64],

Cumâ¢(ğ‘´â¢ğ’„)=âˆ‘i=1dCÎºiâ¢ğ’iâˆ˜ğ’iâˆ˜ğ’iâˆ˜ğ’iCumğ‘´ğ’„superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğœ…ğ‘–subscriptğ’ğ‘–subscriptğ’ğ‘–subscriptğ’ğ‘–subscriptğ’ğ‘–\displaystyle{\rm Cum}(\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c})=\sum_{i=1}^{d_{\rm C}}\kappa_{i}% \boldsymbol{m}_{i}\circ\boldsymbol{m}_{i}\circ\boldsymbol{m}_{i}\circ% \boldsymbol{m}_{i}roman_Cum ( bold_italic_M bold_italic_c ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ˜ bold_italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ˜ bold_italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ˜ bold_italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (6bo)

where âˆ˜\circâˆ˜ is the outer product, Îºisubscriptğœ…ğ‘–\kappa_{i}italic_Îº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the kurtosis of component cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and ğ’i,iâˆˆ[dC]subscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‘C\boldsymbol{m}_{i},~{}i\in[d_{\rm C}]bold_italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] are the columns of ğ‘´ğ‘´\boldsymbol{M}bold_italic_M.

Since ğ‘´â¢ğ’„â¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢ğ’„ğ‘´ğ’„\xlongequalğ–½ğ’„\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c}\xlongequal{({\sf d})}\bm{c}bold_italic_M bold_italic_c ( sansserif_d ) bold_italic_c, the following should hold

Cumâ¢(ğ‘´â¢ğ’„)=Cumâ¢(ğ’„)=Cumâ¢(ğ‘°â¢ğ’„)Cumğ‘´ğ’„Cumğ’„Cumğ‘°ğ’„\displaystyle{\rm Cum}(\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c})={\rm Cum}(\bm{c})={\rm Cum}(\bm{I% }\bm{c})roman_Cum ( bold_italic_M bold_italic_c ) = roman_Cum ( bold_italic_c ) = roman_Cum ( bold_italic_I bold_italic_c ) (6bp)
âŸ¹\displaystyle\impliesâŸ¹ âˆ‘d=1dCÎºdâ¢ğ’dâˆ˜ğ’dâˆ˜ğ’dâˆ˜ğ’d=âˆ‘d=1dCÎºdâ¢ğ’†dâˆ˜ğ’†dâˆ˜ğ’†dâˆ˜ğ’†d,superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘1subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğœ…ğ‘‘subscriptğ’ğ‘‘subscriptğ’ğ‘‘subscriptğ’ğ‘‘subscriptğ’ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘1subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğœ…ğ‘‘subscriptğ’†ğ‘‘subscriptğ’†ğ‘‘subscriptğ’†ğ‘‘subscriptğ’†ğ‘‘\displaystyle\sum_{d=1}^{d_{\rm C}}\kappa_{d}~{}\boldsymbol{m}_{d}\circ% \boldsymbol{m}_{d}\circ\boldsymbol{m}_{d}\circ\boldsymbol{m}_{d}=\sum_{d=1}^{d% _{\rm C}}\kappa_{d}~{}\boldsymbol{e}_{d}\circ\boldsymbol{e}_{d}\circ% \boldsymbol{e}_{d}\circ\boldsymbol{e}_{d},âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ˜ bold_italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ˜ bold_italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ˜ bold_italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ˜ bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ˜ bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ˜ bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (6bq)

ğ’†isubscriptğ’†ğ‘–\boldsymbol{e}_{i}bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the iğ‘–iitalic_ith column of identity matrix ğ‘°ğ‘°\bm{I}bold_italic_I.

Because of statistical independence of components of ğ’„ğ’„\boldsymbol{c}bold_italic_c, the CP-decomposition of Cumâ¢(ğ‘´â¢ğ’„)=Cumâ¢(ğ‘°â¢ğ’„)Cumğ‘´ğ’„Cumğ‘°ğ’„{\rm Cum}(\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c})={\rm Cum}(\bm{I}\bm{c})roman_Cum ( bold_italic_M bold_italic_c ) = roman_Cum ( bold_italic_I bold_italic_c ) is unique [64] upto permutation and scaling ambiguities, i.e., ğ‘´ğ‘´\boldsymbol{M}bold_italic_M should be a permutation scaling matrix.

Let ğ‘´=ğš·â¢ğšºğ‘´ğš·ğšº\boldsymbol{M}=\bm{\Pi}\bm{\Sigma}bold_italic_M = bold_Î  bold_Î£ where, ğš·âˆˆâ„dCÃ—dCğš·superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘‘C\bm{\Pi}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}\times d_{\rm C}}bold_Î  âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a permutation matrix and ğšº=Diagâ¢(r1,â€¦â¢rdC)âˆˆâ„dCÃ—dCğšºDiagsubscriptğ‘Ÿ1â€¦subscriptğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘‘Csuperscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘‘C\bm{\Sigma}={\rm Diag}(r_{1},\ldots r_{d_{\rm C}})\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}% \times d_{\rm C}}bold_Î£ = roman_Diag ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a diagonal scaling matrix.

Finally, since ciâ¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢kâ¢cj,âˆ€iâ‰ j,âˆ€kâˆˆâ„formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ğ‘–\xlongequalğ–½ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘—for-allğ‘–ğ‘—for-allğ‘˜â„c_{i}\not\xlongequal{({\sf d})}kc_{j},\forall i\neq j,\forall k\in\mathbb{R}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT not ( sansserif_d ) italic_k italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_i â‰  italic_j , âˆ€ italic_k âˆˆ roman_â„, ğ‘´ğ‘´\boldsymbol{M}bold_italic_M has to to be identity matrix. To see the reason, for the sake of contradiction, suppose that either (i) there exist i,jâˆˆ[dC]Ã—[dC]ğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‘Cdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘‘Ci,j\in[d_{\rm C}]\times[d_{\rm C}]italic_i , italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] Ã— [ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] and kâˆˆâ„ğ‘˜â„k\in\mathbb{R}italic_k âˆˆ roman_â„, with iâ‰ jğ‘–ğ‘—i\neq jitalic_i â‰  italic_j such that [ğ‘´â¢ğ’„]i=kâ¢cjsubscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘´ğ’„ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘—[\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c}]_{i}=kc_{j}[ bold_italic_M bold_italic_c ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, or (ii) âˆƒiâˆˆ[dC]ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‘C\exists i\in[d_{\rm C}]âˆƒ italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] such that [ğ‘´â¢ğ’„]i=kâ¢cisubscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘´ğ’„ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘–[\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c}]_{i}=kc_{i}[ bold_italic_M bold_italic_c ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for some kâˆˆâ„,kâ‰ 1formulae-sequenceğ‘˜â„ğ‘˜1k\in\mathbb{R},k\neq 1italic_k âˆˆ roman_â„ , italic_k â‰  1.

For case (i), since ğ‘´â¢ğ’„â¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢ğ’„ğ‘´ğ’„\xlongequalğ–½ğ’„\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c}\xlongequal{({\sf d})}\bm{c}bold_italic_M bold_italic_c ( sansserif_d ) bold_italic_c, [ğ‘´â¢ğ’„]iâ¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢ci,âˆ€isubscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘´ğ’„ğ‘–\xlongequalğ–½subscriptğ‘ğ‘–for-allğ‘–[\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c}]_{i}\xlongequal{({\sf d})}c_{i},\forall i[ bold_italic_M bold_italic_c ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( sansserif_d ) italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_i. Hence,

[ğ‘´â¢ğ’„]i=kâ¢cjsubscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘´ğ’„ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\displaystyle[\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c}]_{i}=kc_{j}[ bold_italic_M bold_italic_c ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
âŸ¹\displaystyle\impliesâŸ¹ [ğ‘´â¢ğ’„]iâ¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢kâ¢cjsubscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘´ğ’„ğ‘–\xlongequalğ–½ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\displaystyle[\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c}]_{i}\xlongequal{({\sf d})}kc_{j}[ bold_italic_M bold_italic_c ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( sansserif_d ) italic_k italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
âŸ¹\displaystyle\impliesâŸ¹ ciâ¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢kâ¢cj,subscriptğ‘ğ‘–\xlongequalğ–½ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\displaystyle c_{i}\xlongequal{({\sf d})}kc_{j},italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( sansserif_d ) italic_k italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

which is a contradiction to the assumption ciâ‰ (ğ–½)kâ¢cjsuperscriptğ–½subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘—c_{i}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle({\sf d})}}{{\neq}}kc_{j}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG â‰  end_ARG start_ARG ( sansserif_d ) end_ARG end_RELOP italic_k italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

For case (ii), [ğ‘´â¢ğ’„]i=kâ¢cjsubscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘´ğ’„ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘—[\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c}]_{i}=kc_{j}[ bold_italic_M bold_italic_c ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT implies that ciâ¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢kâ¢cjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–\xlongequalğ–½ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘—c_{i}\xlongequal{({\sf d})}kc_{j}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( sansserif_d ) italic_k italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. First, kâ‰ Â±1ğ‘˜plus-or-minus1k\neq\pm 1italic_k â‰  Â± 1, cannot hold because it will mean that varâ¢(ci)=k2â¢varâ¢(ci)varsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptğ‘˜2varsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–{\rm var}(c_{i})=k^{2}{\rm var}(c_{i})roman_var ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_var ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) which cannot hold for kâ‰ Â±1ğ‘˜plus-or-minus1k\neq\pm 1italic_k â‰  Â± 1 since varâ¢(ci)>0varsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–0{\rm var}(c_{i})>0roman_var ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > 0. Hence, the only possible option is k=âˆ’1ğ‘˜1k=-1italic_k = - 1, which is already ruled out by the assumption that ciâ‰ (ğ–½)âˆ’cisuperscriptğ–½subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle({\sf d})}}{{\neq}}-c_{i}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG â‰  end_ARG start_ARG ( sansserif_d ) end_ARG end_RELOP - italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Hence ğ‘´ğ‘´\boldsymbol{M}bold_italic_M is an identity matrix. This concludes the proof.

B.3 Considering Assumption (b)

Let

ğ’†i=[0,0,â€¦,1iâ¢th location,0,0]âˆˆâ„dCsubscriptğ’†ğ‘–00â€¦ğ‘–th location100superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘C\boldsymbol{e}_{i}=[0,0,~{}\dots,\underset{i\text{th location}}{1},0,0]\in% \mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}}bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ 0 , 0 , â€¦ , start_UNDERACCENT italic_i th location end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG 1 end_ARG , 0 , 0 ] âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

denote the standard basis vector in â„dCsuperscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘C\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}}roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let ğ’—i=aiâ¢ğ’†i=ğš²â¢ğ’†isubscriptğ’—ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ’†ğ‘–ğš²subscriptğ’†ğ‘–\boldsymbol{v}_{i}=a_{i}\boldsymbol{e}_{i}={\bm{\Lambda}}\boldsymbol{e}_{i}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_Î› bold_italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where

ğš²=Diagâ¢([a1,â€¦,adC]T),ğš²Diagsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘‘Cğ‘‡\displaystyle{\bm{\Lambda}}={\rm Diag}([a_{1},\dots,a_{d_{\rm C}}]^{T}),bold_Î› = roman_Diag ( [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ,

where Diagâ¢(â‹…)Diagâ‹…{\rm Diag}(\cdot)roman_Diag ( â‹… ) represents the diagonal matrix formed by the given vector.

If ğ‘´â¢ğ’„â¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢ğ’„ğ‘´ğ’„\xlongequalğ–½ğ’„\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c}\xlongequal{({\sf d})}\bm{c}bold_italic_M bold_italic_c ( sansserif_d ) bold_italic_c, then the supports of ğ‘´â¢ğ’„ğ‘´ğ’„\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c}bold_italic_M bold_italic_c and ğ’„ğ’„\bm{c}bold_italic_c should match, i.e.,

ğ‘´â¢(ğ’)=ğ’,ğ‘´ğ’ğ’\boldsymbol{M}(\mathcal{C})=\mathcal{C},bold_italic_M ( caligraphic_C ) = caligraphic_C ,

where ğ‘´â¢(ğ’)={ğ‘´â¢ğ’„|ğ’„âˆˆğ’}ğ‘´ğ’conditional-setğ‘´ğ’„ğ’„ğ’\boldsymbol{M}(\mathcal{C})=\{\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c}~{}|~{}\bm{c}\in\mathcal{C}\}bold_italic_M ( caligraphic_C ) = { bold_italic_M bold_italic_c | bold_italic_c âˆˆ caligraphic_C }.

Note that âˆ€ğ’„âˆˆğ’for-allğ’„ğ’\forall\bm{c}\in\mathcal{C}âˆ€ bold_italic_c âˆˆ caligraphic_C, the set of points ğ’—isubscriptğ’—ğ‘–\boldsymbol{v}_{i}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfy the following property

ğ’„ğ’„\displaystyle\bm{c}bold_italic_c =âˆ‘i=1dCÎ±iâ¢ğ’—i,for someÂ âˆ’1â‰¤Î±iâ‰¤1formulae-sequenceabsentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–subscriptğ’—ğ‘–for someÂ 1subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–1\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{d_{\rm C}}\alpha_{i}\boldsymbol{v}_{i},\quad\quad% \text{for some }-1\leq\alpha_{i}\leq 1= âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , for some - 1 â‰¤ italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 1 (6br)
âŸ¹ğ‘´â¢ğ’„absentğ‘´ğ’„\displaystyle\implies\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c}âŸ¹ bold_italic_M bold_italic_c =âˆ‘i=1dCÎ±iâ¢(ğ‘´â¢ğ’—i).absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘´subscriptğ’—ğ‘–\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{d_{\rm C}}\alpha_{i}(\boldsymbol{M}\boldsymbol{v}_{i% }).= âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_M bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

Since the support of ğ‘´â¢ğ’„ğ‘´ğ’„\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c}bold_italic_M bold_italic_c is ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C, this implies that âˆ€ğ’„âˆˆğ’for-allğ’„ğ’\forall\bm{c}\in\mathcal{C}âˆ€ bold_italic_c âˆˆ caligraphic_C,

ğ’„ğ’„\displaystyle\bm{c}bold_italic_c =âˆ‘i=1dCÎ±iâ¢(ğ‘´â¢ğ’—i),for someÂ âˆ’1â‰¤Î±iâ‰¤1formulae-sequenceabsentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘´subscriptğ’—ğ‘–for someÂ 1subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–1\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{d_{\rm C}}\alpha_{i}(\boldsymbol{M}\boldsymbol{v}_{i% }),\quad\quad\text{for some }-1\leq\alpha_{i}\leq 1= âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_M bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , for some - 1 â‰¤ italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 1

The last equation implies that the set of points ğ‘´â¢ğ’—i,âˆ€iâˆˆ[D]ğ‘´subscriptğ’—ğ‘–for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ·\boldsymbol{M}\boldsymbol{v}_{i},\forall i\in[D]bold_italic_M bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_D ] also satisfy property (6br). Hence, for each iâˆˆ[D]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ·i\in[D]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_D ], ğ‘´â¢ğ’—i=Â±ğ’—jğ‘´subscriptğ’—ğ‘–plus-or-minussubscriptğ’—ğ‘—\boldsymbol{M}\boldsymbol{v}_{i}=\pm\boldsymbol{v}_{j}bold_italic_M bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = Â± bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for some unique jâˆˆ[D]ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ·j\in[D]italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_D ]. Note that jğ‘—jitalic_j should be unique for each iğ‘–iitalic_i because ğ‘´ğ‘´\boldsymbol{M}bold_italic_M is invertible, hence ğ‘´ğ‘´\boldsymbol{M}bold_italic_M cannot map two orthogonal vectors ğ’—isubscriptğ’—ğ‘–\boldsymbol{v}_{i}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ’—ksubscriptğ’—ğ‘˜\boldsymbol{v}_{k}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, iâ‰ kğ‘–ğ‘˜i\neq kitalic_i â‰  italic_k, to the same vector Â±ğ’—jplus-or-minussubscriptğ’—ğ‘—\pm\boldsymbol{v}_{j}Â± bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with same or different signs.

Let ğ‘½=[ğ’—1,â€¦,ğ’—dC]Tğ‘½superscriptsubscriptğ’—1â€¦subscriptğ’—subscriptğ‘‘Cğ‘‡\boldsymbol{V}=[\boldsymbol{v}_{1},\dots,\boldsymbol{v}_{d_{\rm C}}]^{T}bold_italic_V = [ bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then one can write

ğ‘´â¢ğ‘½=ğ‘½â¢ğšºâ¢ğš·,ğ‘´ğ‘½ğ‘½ğšºğš·\boldsymbol{M}\boldsymbol{V}=\boldsymbol{V}\bm{\Sigma}\bm{\Pi},bold_italic_M bold_italic_V = bold_italic_V bold_Î£ bold_Î  ,

where ğšºğšº\bm{\Sigma}bold_Î£ is some diagonal matrix with diagonal entries from {+1,âˆ’1}11\{+1,-1\}{ + 1 , - 1 } and ğš·ğš·\bm{\Pi}bold_Î  is a permutation matrix. Then the above implies

ğ‘´â¢ğš²â¢ğ‘°ğ‘´ğš²ğ‘°\displaystyle\boldsymbol{M}{\bm{\Lambda}}\bm{I}bold_italic_M bold_Î› bold_italic_I =ğš²â¢ğ‘°â¢ğšºâ¢ğš·absentğš²ğ‘°ğšºğš·\displaystyle={\bm{\Lambda}}\bm{I}\bm{\Sigma}\bm{\Pi}= bold_Î› bold_italic_I bold_Î£ bold_Î 
âŸ¹ğ‘´absentğ‘´\displaystyle\implies\boldsymbol{M}âŸ¹ bold_italic_M =ğš²â¢ğšºâ¢ğš·â¢ğš²âˆ’1.absentğš²ğšºğš·superscriptğš²1\displaystyle={\bm{\Lambda}}\bm{\Sigma}\bm{\Pi}\bm{\bm{\Lambda}}^{-1}.= bold_Î› bold_Î£ bold_Î  bold_Î› start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Hence ğ‘´ğ‘´\boldsymbol{M}bold_italic_M is a permutation and scaling matrix.

Finally, by the same argument presented in last paragraph of Sec. B.2 (i.e., proof with Assumption (a)), we conclude that ğ‘´ğ‘´\boldsymbol{M}bold_italic_M is an identity matrix.

Appendix C Proof of TheoremÂ 2

We restate the theorem here: {mdframed}[backgroundcolor=gray!10,topline=false, rightline=false, leftline=false, bottomline=false] TheoremÂ 2 Consider the mixture model in (6h). Assume that rankâ¢(ğ‘¨)=dC+dPrankğ‘¨subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘‘P{\rm rank}(\boldsymbol{A})=d_{\rm C}+d_{\rm P}roman_rank ( bold_italic_A ) = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and rankâ¢(ğ”¼â¢[ğ’„â¢ğ’„âŠ¤])=dCrankğ”¼delimited-[]ğ’„superscriptğ’„topsubscriptğ‘‘C{\rm rank}(\mathbb{E}[\bm{c}\bm{c}^{\!\top\!}])={d_{\rm C}}roman_rank ( roman_ğ”¼ [ bold_italic_c bold_italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ) = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and that AssumptionÂ 2 holds. Denote ğ‘¸^^ğ‘¸\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG as any solution of (6) by constraining ğ‘¸=ğ‘¸(1)=ğ‘¸(2)ğ‘¸superscriptğ‘¸1superscriptğ‘¸2\boldsymbol{Q}=\boldsymbol{Q}^{(1)}=\boldsymbol{Q}^{(2)}bold_italic_Q = bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, we have ğ‘¸^â¢ğ’™(q)=ğš¯â¢ğ’„^ğ‘¸superscriptğ’™ğ‘ğš¯ğ’„\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}\bm{c}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ bold_italic_c.

One can follow the same argument as in the step 1 of proof in B.

Let us define

ğ‘¯=ğ‘¸â¢ğ‘¨âˆˆâ„dCÃ—(dC+dP).ğ‘¯ğ‘¸ğ‘¨superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘‘P\boldsymbol{H}=\boldsymbol{Q}\boldsymbol{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}\times(d_{% \rm C}+d_{\rm P})}.bold_italic_H = bold_italic_Q bold_italic_A âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— ( italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

We want to show that

Nullâ¢(ğ‘¯)=ğŸÃ—â„dP,Nullğ‘¯0superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘P\displaystyle{\rm Null}(\boldsymbol{H})=\boldsymbol{0}\times\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm P% }},roman_Null ( bold_italic_H ) = bold_0 Ã— roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (6bs)

since this will imply that that ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}bold_italic_H does not depend upon the style component. Combined with the fact that rankâ¢(ğ‘¯)=dCrankğ‘¯subscriptğ‘‘C{\rm rank}(\boldsymbol{H})=d_{\rm C}roman_rank ( bold_italic_H ) = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, this will imply that ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}bold_italic_H is an invertible function of the content component. To that end, consider the following line of arguments.

Since the objective in (6) matches the distribution for latent random variables ğ’„^(1)=ğ‘¸â¢ğ’™(1)superscript^ğ’„1ğ‘¸superscriptğ’™1\widehat{\bm{c}}^{(1)}=\boldsymbol{Q}\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_Q bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ’„^(2)=ğ‘¸â¢ğ’™(2)superscript^ğ’„2ğ‘¸superscriptğ’™2\widehat{\bm{c}}^{(2)}=\boldsymbol{Q}\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_Q bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the following holds for any â„›câŠ†â„dC,subscriptâ„›ğ‘superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘C\mathcal{R}_{c}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}},caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,, âˆƒkâˆˆâ„ğ‘˜â„\exists~{}k\in\mathbb{R}âˆƒ italic_k âˆˆ roman_â„

â„™ğ’„^(1)â¢[kâ¢â„›c]subscriptâ„™superscript^ğ’„1delimited-[]ğ‘˜subscriptâ„›ğ‘\displaystyle\mathbb{P}_{\widehat{\bm{c}}^{(1)}}[k\mathcal{R}_{c}]roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] =â„™ğ’„^(2)â¢[kâ¢â„›c],absentsubscriptâ„™superscript^ğ’„2delimited-[]ğ‘˜subscriptâ„›ğ‘\displaystyle=\mathbb{P}_{\widehat{\bm{c}}^{(2)}}[k\mathcal{R}_{c}],= roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ,
â‡”(a)â„™ğ’›(1)â¢[ğ‘¯PreImgâ¢(kâ¢â„›c)]superscriptiffğ‘absentsubscriptâ„™superscriptğ’›1delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¯PreImgğ‘˜subscriptâ„›ğ‘\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(a)}}{{\iff}}\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{z}^{(% 1)}}[\boldsymbol{H}_{\rm PreImg}(k\mathcal{R}_{c})]start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG â‡” end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_a ) end_ARG end_RELOP roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_PreImg end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] =â„™ğ’›(2)â¢[ğ‘¯PreImgâ¢(kâ¢â„›c)]absentsubscriptâ„™superscriptğ’›2delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¯PreImgğ‘˜subscriptâ„›ğ‘\displaystyle=\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{z}^{(2)}}[\boldsymbol{H}_{\rm PreImg}(k% \mathcal{R}_{c})]= roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_PreImg end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] (6bt)
â‡”(b)â„™ğ’›(1)â¢[kâ¢ğ‘¯PreImgâ¢(â„›c)]superscriptiffğ‘absentsubscriptâ„™superscriptğ’›1delimited-[]ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¯PreImgsubscriptâ„›ğ‘\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(b)}}{{\iff}}\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{z}^{(% 1)}}[k\boldsymbol{H}_{\rm PreImg}(\mathcal{R}_{c})]start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG â‡” end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_b ) end_ARG end_RELOP roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k bold_italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_PreImg end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] =â„™ğ’›(2)â¢[kâ¢ğ‘¯PreImgâ¢(â„›c)],absentsubscriptâ„™superscriptğ’›2delimited-[]ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¯PreImgsubscriptâ„›ğ‘\displaystyle=\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{z}^{(2)}}[k\boldsymbol{H}_{\rm PreImg}(% \mathcal{R}_{c})],= roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k bold_italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_PreImg end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] , (6bu)

where, ğ‘¯PreImgâ¢(â„›c):={ğ’›|ğ‘¯â¢ğ’›âˆˆâ„›c}assignsubscriptğ‘¯PreImgsubscriptâ„›ğ‘conditional-setğ’›ğ‘¯ğ’›subscriptâ„›ğ‘\boldsymbol{H}_{\rm PreImg}(\mathcal{R}_{c}):=\{\boldsymbol{z}~{}|~{}% \boldsymbol{H}\boldsymbol{z}\in\mathcal{R}_{c}\}bold_italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_PreImg end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) := { bold_italic_z | bold_italic_H bold_italic_z âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is the pre-image of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}bold_italic_H. (a)ğ‘(a)( italic_a ) follows because â„™ğ’„^(q)â¢[kâ¢â„›c]=â„™ğ‘¯â¢ğ’›(q)â¢[kâ¢â„›c]=â„™ğ’›(q)â¢[ğ‘¯PreImgâ¢(kâ¢â„›c)]subscriptâ„™superscript^ğ’„ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘˜subscriptâ„›ğ‘subscriptâ„™ğ‘¯superscriptğ’›ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘˜subscriptâ„›ğ‘subscriptâ„™superscriptğ’›ğ‘delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¯PreImgğ‘˜subscriptâ„›ğ‘\mathbb{P}_{\widehat{\bm{c}}^{(q)}}[k\mathcal{R}_{c}]=\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{% H}\boldsymbol{z}^{(q)}}[k\mathcal{R}_{c}]=\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{z}^{(q)}}[% \boldsymbol{H}_{\rm PreImg}(k\mathcal{R}_{c})]roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_H bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_PreImg end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] [63, Section 2.2]. (b)ğ‘(b)( italic_b ) follows because ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}bold_italic_H is a linear operation.

Although (6bt) holds for any â„›csubscriptâ„›ğ‘\mathcal{R}_{c}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we will see that it is sufficient to consider a special â„›csubscriptâ„›ğ‘\mathcal{R}_{c}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to prove (6bs). To that end, take â„›c=convâ¢{ğŸ,ğ’‚1,â€¦,ğ’‚dC}subscriptâ„›ğ‘conv0subscriptğ’‚1â€¦subscriptğ’‚subscriptğ‘‘C\mathcal{R}_{c}={\rm conv}\{\boldsymbol{0},\boldsymbol{a}_{1},\ldots,% \boldsymbol{a}_{d_{\rm C}}\}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_conv { bold_0 , bold_italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , bold_italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, where ğ’‚iâˆˆâ„dCsubscriptğ’‚ğ‘–superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘C\boldsymbol{a}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}}bold_italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that â„™ğ’„^(q)â¢[â„›c]>0subscriptâ„™superscript^ğ’„ğ‘delimited-[]subscriptâ„›ğ‘0\mathbb{P}_{\widehat{\bm{c}}^{(q)}}[\mathcal{R}_{c}]>0roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] > 0. Let us take ğ’šiâˆˆâ„dC+dPsubscriptğ’šğ‘–superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘‘P\boldsymbol{y}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}+d_{\rm P}}bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, such that ğ‘¯â¢ğ’ši=ğ’‚iğ‘¯subscriptğ’šğ‘–subscriptğ’‚ğ‘–\boldsymbol{H}\boldsymbol{y}_{i}=\boldsymbol{a}_{i}bold_italic_H bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For reasons that will be clear later, we hope to show that

ğ‘¯PreImgâ¢(â„›c)=convâ¢{ğŸ,ğ’š1,â€¦,ğ’šdC}+Nullâ¢(ğ‘¯).subscriptğ‘¯PreImgsubscriptâ„›ğ‘conv0subscriptğ’š1â€¦subscriptğ’šsubscriptğ‘‘CNullğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}_{\rm PreImg}(\mathcal{R}_{c})={\rm conv}\{\boldsymbol{0},% \boldsymbol{y}_{1},\dots,\boldsymbol{y}_{d_{\rm C}}\}+{\rm Null}(\boldsymbol{H% }).bold_italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_PreImg end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = roman_conv { bold_0 , bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } + roman_Null ( bold_italic_H ) .

To that end, observe that for any ğ’“âˆˆâ„›cğ’“subscriptâ„›ğ‘\boldsymbol{r}\in\mathcal{R}_{c}bold_italic_r âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we can represent ğ’“ğ’“\boldsymbol{r}bold_italic_r as,

ğ’“=1dC+1â¢âˆ‘i=1dCwiâ¢ğ’‚i,Â for someÂ â¢{wi}i=1dCâ¢s.t.âˆ‘i=1dCwiâ‰¤1,âˆ€i.formulae-sequenceğ’“1subscriptğ‘‘C1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ’‚ğ‘–Â for someÂ superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘Cğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–1for-allğ‘–\displaystyle\boldsymbol{r}=\frac{1}{d_{\rm C}+1}\sum_{i=1}^{d_{\rm C}}w_{i}% \boldsymbol{a}_{i},\text{ for some }\{w_{i}\}_{i=1}^{d_{\rm C}}~{}{s.t.}~{}% \sum_{i=1}^{d_{\rm C}}w_{i}\leq 1,~{}\forall i.bold_italic_r = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , for some { italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s . italic_t . âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 1 , âˆ€ italic_i .

For both view q=1,2ğ‘12q=1,2italic_q = 1 , 2, we get,

ğ’“ğ’“\displaystyle\boldsymbol{r}bold_italic_r =1dC+1â¢âˆ‘i=1dCwiâ¢ğ‘¯â¢ğ’šiabsent1subscriptğ‘‘C1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘¯subscriptğ’šğ‘–\displaystyle=\frac{1}{d_{\rm C}+1}\sum_{i=1}^{d_{\rm C}}w_{i}\boldsymbol{H}% \boldsymbol{y}_{i}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_H bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
âŸ¹ğ’“absentğ’“\displaystyle\implies\boldsymbol{r}âŸ¹ bold_italic_r =ğ‘¯â¢(1dC+1â¢âˆ‘i=1dCwiâ¢ğ’ši)absentğ‘¯1subscriptğ‘‘C1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ’šğ‘–\displaystyle=\boldsymbol{H}\left(\frac{1}{d_{\rm C}+1}\sum_{i=1}^{d_{\rm C}}w% _{i}\boldsymbol{y}_{i}\right)= bold_italic_H ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

We can write,

We have that Nullâ¢(ğ‘¯)âŠ‚â„dC+dPNullğ‘¯superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘Csubscriptğ‘‘P{\rm Null}(\boldsymbol{H})\subset\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}+d_{\rm P}}roman_Null ( bold_italic_H ) âŠ‚ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a linear subspace with dimâ¢(Nullâ¢(ğ‘¯))=dPdimNullğ‘¯subscriptğ‘‘P{\rm dim}({\rm Null}(\boldsymbol{H}))=d_{\rm P}roman_dim ( roman_Null ( bold_italic_H ) ) = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let ğ’œ=ğ‘¯PreImgâ¢(â„›c)ğ’œsubscriptğ‘¯PreImgsubscriptâ„›ğ‘\mathcal{A}={\boldsymbol{H}_{\rm PreImg}(\mathcal{R}_{c})}caligraphic_A = bold_italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_PreImg end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Note that â„™ğ’›(1)â¢[kâ¢ğ’œ]=â„™ğ’›(2)â¢[kâ¢ğ’œ],âˆ€kâˆˆâ„formulae-sequencesubscriptâ„™superscriptğ’›1delimited-[]ğ‘˜ğ’œsubscriptâ„™superscriptğ’›2delimited-[]ğ‘˜ğ’œfor-allğ‘˜â„\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{z}^{(1)}}[k\mathcal{A}]=\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{z}^{(2% )}}[k\mathcal{A}],\forall k\in\mathbb{R}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k caligraphic_A ] = roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k caligraphic_A ] , âˆ€ italic_k âˆˆ roman_â„ (from (6bt), and â„™ğ’›(q)â¢[ğ’œ]>0subscriptâ„™superscriptğ’›ğ‘delimited-[]ğ’œ0\mathbb{P}_{\boldsymbol{z}^{(q)}}[\mathcal{A}]>0roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ caligraphic_A ] > 0 (by the construction of â„›csubscriptâ„›ğ‘\mathcal{R}_{c}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Further, the set ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is of the form

convâ¢{ğŸ,ğ’š1,â€¦,ğ’šdC}+ğ’«,conv0subscriptğ’š1â€¦subscriptğ’šsubscriptğ‘‘Cğ’«{\rm conv}\{\boldsymbol{0},\boldsymbol{y}_{1},\dots,\boldsymbol{y}_{d_{\rm C}}% \}+\mathcal{P},roman_conv { bold_0 , bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } + caligraphic_P ,

because Nullâ¢(ğ‘¯)Nullğ‘¯{\rm Null}(\boldsymbol{H})roman_Null ( bold_italic_H ) is a subspace of dimension dPsubscriptğ‘‘Pd_{\rm P}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, hence it satisfies the definition of ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. Hence, Assumption 2 implies that

Nullâ¢(ğ‘¯)=ğŸÃ—â„dP.Nullğ‘¯0superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘P{\rm Null}(\boldsymbol{H})=\boldsymbol{0}\times\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm P}}.roman_Null ( bold_italic_H ) = bold_0 Ã— roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Denoting the Nğ‘Nitalic_Nth to Mğ‘€Mitalic_Mth columns of ğ‘¯ğ‘¯\boldsymbol{H}bold_italic_H by ğ‘¯(N:M)\boldsymbol{H}(N:M)bold_italic_H ( italic_N : italic_M ), the above is equivalent to saying

ğ‘¯(dğ‘ª+1:dğ‘ª+dğ‘·)=0.\displaystyle\boldsymbol{H}(d_{\bm{C}}+1:d_{\bm{C}}+d_{\bm{P}})=0.bold_italic_H ( italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 : italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0 . (6bx)

Denote,

ğš¯=ğ‘¯(1:dğ‘ª)âˆ€v=1,2.\bm{\Theta}=\boldsymbol{H}(1:d_{\bm{C}})~{}\forall~{}v=1,2.bold_Î˜ = bold_italic_H ( 1 : italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ€ italic_v = 1 , 2 .

Then, we can write,

ğ‘¸â¢ğ’™(q)=ğš¯â¢ğ’„,âˆ€v=1,2.formulae-sequenceğ‘¸superscriptğ’™ğ‘ğš¯ğ’„for-allğ‘£12\displaystyle\boldsymbol{Q}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}\bm{c},~{}\forall~{% }v=1,2.bold_italic_Q bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ bold_italic_c , âˆ€ italic_v = 1 , 2 . (6by)

This concludes the proof.

Appendix D Proof of TheoremÂ 3

We restate the theorem here: {mdframed}[backgroundcolor=gray!10,topline=false, rightline=false, leftline=false, bottomline=false] TheoremÂ 3 Assume that Assumption 1 is satisfied, that |â„’|â‰¥dCâ„’subscriptğ‘‘C|{\mathcal{L}}|\geq d_{\rm C}| caligraphic_L | â‰¥ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT paired samples (ğ’™â„“(1),ğ’™â„“(2))superscriptsubscriptğ’™â„“1superscriptsubscriptğ’™â„“2(\boldsymbol{x}_{\ell}^{(1)},\boldsymbol{x}_{\ell}^{(2)})( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) are available, that ğ‘¨(q),q=1,2formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘¨ğ‘ğ‘12\bm{A}^{(q)},~{}q=1,2bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_q = 1 , 2 have full column rank, and that â„™ğ’„subscriptâ„™ğ’„\mathbb{P}_{\bm{c}}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is absolutely continuous. Denote (ğ‘¸^(1),ğ‘¸^(2))superscript^ğ‘¸1superscript^ğ‘¸2(\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(1)},\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(2)})( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) as any optimal solution of (6) under the constraint (6i). Then, we have ğ‘¸^(q)â¢ğ’™(q)=ğš¯â¢ğ’„superscript^ğ‘¸ğ‘superscriptğ’™ğ‘ğš¯ğ’„\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}\bm{c}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ bold_italic_c. From our objective in (6), we obtain

ğ‘¸(1)â¢ğ’™(1)superscriptğ‘¸1superscriptğ’™1\displaystyle\boldsymbol{Q}^{(1)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT \xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢ğ‘¸(2)â¢ğ’™(2).\xlongequalğ–½superscriptğ‘¸2superscriptğ’™2\displaystyle\xlongequal{({\sf d})}\boldsymbol{Q}^{(2)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}.( sansserif_d ) bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (6bz)

Using Assumption 1 and following the proof of step 1 in Theorem B, we can obtain:

ğ‘¸(q)â¢ğ’™(q)=ğš¯(q)â¢ğ’„,âˆ€q=1,2,formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘superscriptğ’™ğ‘superscriptğš¯ğ‘ğ’„for-allğ‘12\boldsymbol{Q}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}={\bm{\Theta}}^{(q)}\bm{c},~{}\forall q% =1,2,bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c , âˆ€ italic_q = 1 , 2 ,

for some invertible matrices ğš¯(q),âˆ€qsuperscriptğš¯ğ‘for-allğ‘\bm{\Theta}^{(q)},\forall qbold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_q. Hence,

ğš¯(1)â¢ğ’„superscriptğš¯1ğ’„\displaystyle\bm{\Theta}^{(1)}\bm{c}bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c \xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢ğš¯(2)â¢ğ’„\xlongequalğ–½superscriptğš¯2ğ’„\displaystyle\xlongequal{({\sf d})}\bm{\Theta}^{(2)}\bm{c}( sansserif_d ) bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c (6ca)
âŸ¹ğ’„absentğ’„\displaystyle\implies\bm{c}âŸ¹ bold_italic_c \xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢(ğš¯(1))âˆ’1â¢ğš¯(2)â¢ğ’„.\xlongequalğ–½superscriptsuperscriptğš¯11superscriptğš¯2ğ’„\displaystyle\xlongequal{({\sf d})}(\bm{\Theta}^{(1)})^{-1}\bm{\Theta}^{(2)}% \bm{c}.( sansserif_d ) ( bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c . (6cb)

Hence we can have linear transformation ğ‘´:=(ğš¯(1))âˆ’1â¢ğš¯(2)assignğ‘´superscriptsuperscriptğš¯11superscriptğš¯2\boldsymbol{M}:=(\bm{\Theta}^{(1)})^{-1}\bm{\Theta}^{(2)}bold_italic_M := ( bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT which has same probability density as â„™ğ’„subscriptâ„™ğ’„\mathbb{P}_{\bm{c}}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. ğ‘¸(1)â¢ğ’™â„“(1)superscriptğ‘¸1subscriptsuperscriptğ’™1â„“\displaystyle\boldsymbol{Q}^{(1)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}_{\ell}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ğ‘¸(2)â¢ğ’™â„“(2)absentsuperscriptğ‘¸2subscriptsuperscriptğ’™2â„“\displaystyle=\boldsymbol{Q}^{(2)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}_{\ell}= bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
âŸ¹ğš¯(1)â¢ğ’„â„“absentsuperscriptğš¯1subscriptğ’„â„“\displaystyle\implies\bm{\Theta}^{(1)}\bm{c}_{\ell}âŸ¹ bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ğš¯(2)â¢ğ’„â„“absentsuperscriptğš¯2subscriptğ’„â„“\displaystyle=\bm{\Theta}^{(2)}\bm{c}_{\ell}= bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
âŸ¹ğ’„â„“absentsubscriptğ’„â„“\displaystyle\implies\bm{c}_{\ell}âŸ¹ bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =(ğš¯(1))âˆ’1â¢ğš¯(2)â¢ğ’„â„“absentsuperscriptsuperscriptğš¯11superscriptğš¯2subscriptğ’„â„“\displaystyle=(\bm{\Theta}^{(1)})^{-1}\bm{\Theta}^{(2)}\bm{c}_{\ell}= ( bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
âŸ¹ğ’„â„“absentsubscriptğ’„â„“\displaystyle\implies\bm{c}_{\ell}âŸ¹ bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ğ‘´â¢ğ’„â„“.absentğ‘´subscriptğ’„â„“\displaystyle=\boldsymbol{M}\bm{c}_{\ell}.= bold_italic_M bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Let ğ‘ª=[ğ’„1â¢â€¦â¢ğ’„Np]ğ‘ªdelimited-[]subscriptğ’„1â€¦subscriptğ’„subscriptğ‘ğ‘\boldsymbol{C}=[\bm{c}_{1}\dots\bm{c}_{N_{p}}]bold_italic_C = [ bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â€¦ bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]. Then the above implies:

ğ‘ªğ‘ª\displaystyle\boldsymbol{C}bold_italic_C =ğ‘´â¢ğ‘ªabsentğ‘´ğ‘ª\displaystyle=\boldsymbol{M}\boldsymbol{C}= bold_italic_M bold_italic_C
âŸ¹(ğ‘´âˆ’ğ‘°)â¢ğ‘ªabsentğ‘´ğ‘°ğ‘ª\displaystyle\implies(\boldsymbol{M}-\bm{I})\boldsymbol{C}âŸ¹ ( bold_italic_M - bold_italic_I ) bold_italic_C =ğŸ.absent0\displaystyle=\boldsymbol{0}.= bold_0 .

Now we show that ğ‘ªğ‘ª\boldsymbol{C}bold_italic_C is a full row rank matrix, which implies that ğ‘´âˆ’ğ‘°=ğŸâŸ¹ğ‘´=ğ‘°ğ‘´ğ‘°0ğ‘´ğ‘°\boldsymbol{M}-\bm{I}=\boldsymbol{0}\implies\boldsymbol{M}=\bm{I}bold_italic_M - bold_italic_I = bold_0 âŸ¹ bold_italic_M = bold_italic_I. To that end, note that random variables ğ’™i(1)superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–1\boldsymbol{x}_{i}^{(1)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ’™i(2)superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–2\boldsymbol{x}_{i}^{(2)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT being i.i.d implies that ğ’„(i)superscriptğ’„ğ‘–\bm{c}^{(i)}bold_italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are i.i.d from â„™ğ’„subscriptâ„™ğ’„\mathbb{P}_{\bm{c}}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This implies that for any 1â‰¤iâ‰¤|â„’|1ğ‘–â„’1\leq i\leq|\mathcal{L}|1 â‰¤ italic_i â‰¤ | caligraphic_L |,

Prâ¢[ğ’„iâˆˆspanâ¢({ğ’„n1,â€¦,ğ’„ndCâˆ’1})]=0.Prdelimited-[]subscriptğ’„ğ‘–spansubscriptğ’„subscriptğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğ’„subscriptğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘C10\displaystyle{\rm Pr}[\bm{c}_{i}\in{\rm span}(\{\bm{c}_{n_{1}},\dots,\bm{c}_{n% _{d_{\rm C}-1}}\})]=0.roman_Pr [ bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_span ( { bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ) ] = 0 . (6cc)

This is because spanâ¢({ğ’„n1,â€¦,ğ’„ndCâˆ’1})spansubscriptğ’„subscriptğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğ’„subscriptğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘C1{\rm span}(\{\bm{c}_{n_{1}},\dots,\bm{c}_{n_{d_{\rm C}-1}}\})roman_span ( { bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ) for njâˆˆ[|â„’|]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘—delimited-[]â„’n_{j}\in[|\mathcal{L}|]italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ | caligraphic_L | ], is a lower dimensional subspace in â„dCsuperscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘C\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}}roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which has zero probability under absolutely continuous distribution â„™ğ’„subscriptâ„™ğ’„\mathbb{P}_{\bm{c}}roman_â„™ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Hence any dCsubscriptğ‘‘Cd_{\rm C}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT out of |â„’|â„’|\mathcal{L}|| caligraphic_L | column vectors in ğ‘ªğ‘ª\boldsymbol{C}bold_italic_C are linearly independent with probability 1.

This concludes the proof.

Appendix E Detailed Identifiability Conditions of Existing Results

[backgroundcolor=gray!10,topline=false, rightline=false, leftline=false, bottomline=false]

E.2 Identifiability of Unaligned SCA in [8]

We summarize the result in [8] in the following {mdframed}[backgroundcolor=gray!10,topline=false, rightline=false, leftline=false, bottomline=false]

Theorem 5 (Identifiability of Unaligned SCA via ICA [8]).

Appendix F Additional Synthetic Data Experiments

Hyperparameter Settings:

We use Adam optimizer [65] to solve (6g) and learn matrices ğ‘¸(q),q=1,2formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘ğ‘12\boldsymbol{Q}^{(q)},~{}q=1,2bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_q = 1 , 2 and the discriminator fğ‘“fitalic_f. We set the initial learning rate of matrix and discriminator to be 0.0090.0090.0090.009 and 0.000080.000080.000080.00008 respectively. We set the Î»=0.1ğœ†0.1\lambda=0.1italic_Î» = 0.1 in (6g) to enforce (6b). For weak supervision experiment in F, we set Î²=0.01ğ›½0.01\beta=0.01italic_Î² = 0.01 in (6i). We generate total of 100,000 samples in each domain. For our experiment we set the batch size to be 1,000 and run (6g) for 50 epochs. Our discriminator is a 6-layer multilayer perceptron (MLP) with hidden units { 1024, 521, 512, 256, 128, 64 } in each layer. All the layers use leaky ReLU activation functions [66] with a slope of 0.2 except for the last layer which has sigmoid activations. We include a label smoothing coefficient of 0.2 in the discriminator predictions as suggested in [38].

Additional Details for Validation of TheoremÂ 1 in Sec.Â 3:

Here we explain the data generation details of the result shown in Fig.Â 3. For the result in top row, we sample c1subscriptğ‘1c_{1}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from a Gaussian mixture with three Gaussian components. Each component follows a normal distribution ğ’©â¢(Î¼,2)ğ’©ğœ‡2\mathcal{N}(\mu,~{}2)caligraphic_N ( italic_Î¼ , 2 ) where Î¼âˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,10)similar-toğœ‡ğ’©010\mu\sim\mathcal{N}(0,~{}10)italic_Î¼ âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , 10 ). The second component, i.e., c2subscriptğ‘2c_{2}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is independently sampled from the gamma distribution Gammaâ¢(1,3)Gamma13\texttt{Gamma}(1,~{}3)Gamma ( 1 , 3 ). The private components are sampled from p(1)âˆ¼Laplaceâ¢(1.0,6.5)similar-tosuperscriptğ‘1Laplace1.06.5p^{(1)}~{}\sim\texttt{Laplace}(1.0,~{}6.5)italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ Laplace ( 1.0 , 6.5 ) and p(2)âˆ¼Uniformâ¢[âˆ’10,10]similar-tosuperscriptğ‘2Uniform1010p^{(2)}~{}\sim\texttt{Uniform}[-10,~{}10]italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ Uniform [ - 10 , 10 ], both only having one dimension. In the bottom row, we sample ğ’„âˆˆâ„2âˆ¼VonMisesâ¢(2.5,2.0)ğ’„superscriptâ„2similar-toVonMises2.52.0\bm{c}\in\mathbb{R}^{2}\sim~{}\texttt{VonMises}(2.5,~{}2.0)bold_italic_c âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ VonMises ( 2.5 , 2.0 ) distribution. The private components satisfy p(1)âˆ¼Laplaceâ¢(1.0,6.5)similar-tosuperscriptğ‘1Laplace1.06.5p^{(1)}\sim\texttt{Laplace}(1.0,~{}6.5)italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ Laplace ( 1.0 , 6.5 ) and p(2)âˆ¼Gammaâ¢(0.5,3.0)similar-tosuperscriptğ‘2Gamma0.53.0p^{(2)}~{}\sim\texttt{Gamma}(0.5,~{}3.0)italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ Gamma ( 0.5 , 3.0 ). Each element of mixing matrices are sampled from ğ‘¨iâ¢j(q)âˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,1),q=1,2formulae-sequencesimilar-tosuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¨ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘ğ’©01ğ‘12\boldsymbol{A}_{ij}^{(q)}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1),~{}q=1,2bold_italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , 1 ) , italic_q = 1 , 2. The readers are referred to TableÂ 3 for the definition of notations used for distributions.

Validation of TheoremÂ 3. Fig.Â 5 presents numerical validation for TheoremÂ 3.

Data Generation: We set dC=3subscriptğ‘‘C3d_{\rm C}=3italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 3 and dP(q)=1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘ğ‘P1d^{(q)}_{\rm P}=1italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 for q=1,2ğ‘12q=1,2italic_q = 1 , 2. We sample each component of shared component ğ’„iâˆ¼Laplaceâ¢(0.0,6.5)â¢i=1,2,3formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscriptğ’„ğ‘–Laplace0.06.5ğ‘–123\bm{c}_{i}\sim\texttt{Laplace}(0.0,~{}6.5)~{}i=1,2,3bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ Laplace ( 0.0 , 6.5 ) italic_i = 1 , 2 , 3, p(1)âˆˆâ„1âˆ¼Uniformâ¢[âˆ’10,10]superscriptğ‘1superscriptâ„1similar-toUniform1010p^{(1)}\in\mathbb{R}^{1}~{}\sim\texttt{Uniform}[-10,~{}10]italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ Uniform [ - 10 , 10 ] and p(2)âˆ¼Gammaâ¢(0.5,3.0)similar-tosuperscriptğ‘2Gamma0.53.0p^{(2)}\sim\texttt{Gamma}(0.5,~{}3.0)italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ Gamma ( 0.5 , 3.0 ). Although ğ’„ğ’„\boldsymbol{c}bold_italic_c satisfies component-wise independence assumption, it does not satisfy the condition that ciâ‰ (ğ–½)kâ¢cj,âˆ€iâ‰ jformulae-sequencesuperscriptğ–½subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘—for-allğ‘–ğ‘—c_{i}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle({\sf d})}}{{\neq}}kc_{j},\forall i\neq jitalic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG â‰  end_ARG start_ARG ( sansserif_d ) end_ARG end_RELOP italic_k italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_i â‰  italic_j because ciâ¢\xlongequalâ¢(ğ–½)â¢cj,âˆ€i,jâˆˆ[3]subscriptğ‘ğ‘–\xlongequalğ–½subscriptğ‘ğ‘—for-allğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]3c_{i}\xlongequal{({\sf d})}c_{j},\forall i,j\in[3]italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( sansserif_d ) italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_i , italic_j âˆˆ [ 3 ]. Therefore, Theorem 1 does not cover this case. Nonetheless, this case falls under the jurisdiction of TheoremÂ 3.

Result: Fig.Â 5 corroborates with our TheoremÂ 3. That is, one needs at least |â„’|â‰¥dC=3â„’subscriptğ‘‘C3|{\cal L}|\geq d_{\rm C}=3| caligraphic_L | â‰¥ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 3 pairs of â€œanchorsâ€ (i.e., aligned cross domain pairs) to ensure identifiability of ğ’„^(q)=ğš¯â¢ğ’„superscript^ğ’„ğ‘ğš¯ğ’„\widehat{\bm{c}}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}\bm{c}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ bold_italic_c for q=1,2ğ‘12q=1,2italic_q = 1 , 2.

Appendix G Real Data Experiment Settings and Additional Results

G.1 Multi-lingual Information Retrieval

This task aims to associate high-dimensional word embeddings across different languages according to their semantic meaning. The word embeddings in two languages are represented using two sets of vectors, i.e., {ğ’™(1)}superscriptğ’™1\{\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}\}{ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } and {ğ’™(2)}superscriptğ’™2\{\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}\}{ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }. The postulate is that if ğ’™i(1)subscriptsuperscriptğ’™1ğ‘–\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}_{i}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ’™j(2)subscriptsuperscriptğ’™2ğ‘—\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}_{j}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT both mean â€œcatâ€ in two languages (e.g., Chinese and German), they should share some latent components ğ’„ğ’„\bm{c}bold_italic_c.

Dataset: We use the word embeddings from the MUSE dataset (https://github.com/facebookresearch/MUSE) [21]. These monolingual word embedding are generated using fastText [67] and has dimensions of d(q)=300superscriptğ‘‘ğ‘300d^{(q)}=300italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 300 for q=1,2ğ‘12q=1,2italic_q = 1 , 2. The training dataset include 200,000 word embeddings in each language. In our experiment we set dC=256subscriptğ‘‘C256d_{\rm C}=256italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 256. We follow the generative model under (6h) and run the formulation in (6g) to learn the linear transformation ğ‘¸ğ‘¸\boldsymbol{Q}bold_italic_Q.

Hyperparameter Settings: The hyperparameter settings for multi-lingual information retrieval is described in the Table.Â 4.

Baseline: We use Adv [21] as the baseline which also uses distribution matching between two language domains. Unlike our method, Adv does not use linear mixture models.

Metric: We follow [21] to use the average precision score calculated based on nearest neighbor (NN) and cross domain similarity local scaling (CSLS). Precision at kğ‘˜kitalic_k (â€œkğ‘˜kitalic_k precisionâ€) is computed by the number of times that one of the correct translations of source word is retrieved at top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k results (kğ‘˜kitalic_k ={1, 5, 10}). The final score is normalized to be in the range of 0 to 100, with 100 being the highest score indicating the best performance. To evaluate the performance, we use the same test data as in [21]. For each source and target language pair, this dataset includes 1,500 source word embeddings, {ğ’™(1)}superscriptğ’™1\{\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}\}{ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }, which are used to retrieve corresponding embeddings from a pool of 200,000 target word embeddings, {ğ’™(2)}superscriptğ’™2\{\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}\}{ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }.

Result: TableÂ 5 reports the P@1 scores over the test data calculated for each source and target language pair. The languages are encoded as en - English, es - Spanish, it - Italian, fr - French, de - Germany, ru - Russian, ar - Arabic and vi - Vietnamese. One can observe that the proposed method achieves better precision than the Adv in most of the translation tasks. For example, proposed method significantly improves the tasks enâ†’â†’\toâ†’ar, arâ†’â†’\toâ†’en, enâ†’â†’\toâ†’vi and viâ†’â†’\toâ†’en, showing at least gain of 10%percent1010\%10 % in both NN and CSLS based precision. Similarly, our method shows at least 5%percent55\%5 % improvement in both NN and CSLS based precision in enâ†’â†’\toâ†’es and esâ†’â†’\toâ†’en tasks.

Table.Â 6 shows the P@5 and P@10 scores. Similar results are observed.

G.2 Domain Adaptation

Hyperparameter Settings:

The domain adaptation task follows the hyperparameter settings described in Table.Â 7.

Baselines and Training Setup: The baselines are representative DA methods, namely, DANN [25], ADDA[56], DAN[24], JAN[50] ,CDAN[57], MDD[58], and MCC[59]. We use the baseline implementations from the https://github.com/thuml/Transfer-Learning-Library. In all the baselines except for CLIP, the classifier is jointly optimized with their feature extractors, which arguably regularizes towards more classification-friendly geometry of the shared features; see [68, 69]. Following their training strategy, we also append a cross-entropy (CE) based classifier training module to our loss in (6g) (which learns our feature extractor ğ‘¸ğ‘¸\bm{Q}bold_italic_Q). The CE part uses ğ‘¸â¢ğ’™(1)ğ‘¸superscriptğ’™1\bm{Q}\bm{x}^{(1)}bold_italic_Q bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the labels of the sources as inputs to learn the classifier, i.e.,

â„’CE=âˆ’Î³â¢âˆ‘â„“=1Nâˆ‘k=1Kğ•€â¢[yâ„“=k]â¢logâ¡ğ’“ğœ½â¢([ğ‘¸â¢ğ’™â„“(1)]k),subscriptâ„’CEğ›¾superscriptsubscriptâ„“1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğ•€delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¦â„“ğ‘˜subscriptğ’“ğœ½subscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘¸subscriptsuperscriptğ’™1â„“ğ‘˜\displaystyle{\cal L}_{\rm CE}=-\gamma~{}\sum_{\ell=1}^{N}\sum_{k=1}^{K}% \mathbb{I}[y_{\ell}=k]\log\bm{r}_{\bm{\theta}}([\bm{Q}\bm{x}^{(1)}_{\ell}]_{k}),caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_CE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - italic_Î³ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ğ•€ [ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k ] roman_log bold_italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ bold_italic_Q bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (6ef)

where ğ’“ğœ½â¢(â‹…):â„dCâ†’â„K:subscriptğ’“ğœ½â‹…â†’superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘Csuperscriptâ„ğ¾\bm{r}_{\bm{\theta}}(\cdot):\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm C}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{K}bold_italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( â‹… ) : roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the classifier that aims to map the learned feature vector ğ‘¸â¢ğ’™â„“(1)ğ‘¸subscriptsuperscriptğ’™1â„“\bm{Q}\bm{x}^{(1)}_{\ell}bold_italic_Q bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to a Kğ¾Kitalic_K-dimensional probability mass function (i.e., the distribution of the ground-truth label over Kğ¾Kitalic_K classes), yâ„“âˆˆ[K]subscriptğ‘¦â„“delimited-[]ğ¾y_{\ell}\in[K]italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ italic_K ] represents the label of the â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“th sample in source domain, and the indicator function ğ•€â¢[yâ„“=k]=1ğ•€delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¦â„“ğ‘˜1\mathbb{I}[y_{\ell}=k]=1roman_ğ•€ [ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k ] = 1 only when the event yâ„“=ksubscriptğ‘¦â„“ğ‘˜y_{\ell}=kitalic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k happens (other wise ğ•€â¢[yâ„“=k]=0ğ•€delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¦â„“ğ‘˜0\mathbb{I}[y_{\ell}=k]=0roman_ğ•€ [ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k ] = 0. The Î³â‰¥0ğ›¾0\gamma\geq 0italic_Î³ â‰¥ 0 is the tunable parameter. The joint loss is still differentiable, and thus we still use the Adam optimizer to jointly optimize ğ‘¸ğ‘¸\bm{Q}bold_italic_Q and ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}bold_italic_Î¸.

Visualization Result:

Fig.Â 6 shows the 2-dimensional visualization of the CLIP-learned features (d=256ğ‘‘256d=256italic_d = 256) from two domains, namely, DSLR and Amazon images (Office-31), using t-SNE. One can see that CLIP could roughly group the same classes from the two domains together. But the proposed method can further pull the circles and the triangle markers togetherâ€”meaning that the ğ‘¸ğ‘¸\bm{Q}bold_italic_Q really learns shared representations of the same data in the DSLR and Amazon domains.

G.3 Single-cell Sequence Analysis

Hyperparameter Settings:

The hyperparameter settings for single-cell sequence analysis is presented in Table.Â 8.

Baseline:

For more details on baseline refer to the implementation in https://github.com/uhlerlab/cross-modal-autoencoders.

G.4 Computation resources

All the experiments were run on Nvidia H100 GPU. The approximate runtime for a single run of the algorithm is 20 minutes for multi-lingual information retrieval, 15 minutes for domain adaptation, and 3 minutes for single-cell sequence analysis.

Appendix H Extension: Private Component Identification

TheoremsÂ 1-3 are concerned with learning the shared component ğ’„ğ’„\boldsymbol{c}bold_italic_c. The goal, there, was to ensure that ğ‘¸C(q)â¢ğ’™(q)â¢ğš¯â¢ğ’„,âˆ€qsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¸Cğ‘superscriptğ’™ğ‘ğš¯ğ’„for-allğ‘\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm C}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}\bm{\Theta}\bm{c},\forall qbold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Î˜ bold_italic_c , âˆ€ italic_q. In some cases, the private components ğ’‘(q)superscriptğ’‘ğ‘\bm{p}^{(q)}bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is also of interest [6, 31, 70]. To learn ğ’‘(q)superscriptğ’‘ğ‘\bm{p}^{(q)}bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we propose to solve the following learning criterion:
