where ğ’–âŸ‚âŸ‚ğ’—\bm{u}\perp\!\!\!\perp\bm{v}bold_italic_u âŸ‚ âŸ‚ bold_italic_v means that the random vectors ğ’–ğ’–\bm{u}bold_italic_u and ğ’—ğ’—\bm{v}bold_italic_v are independent with each other.

For implementation we use following criterion,

minğ‘¸C(1),ğ‘¸C(2)â¢ğ‘¸P(1),ğ‘¸P(1)â¡maxfâ¡ğ”¼ğ’™(1)â¢logâ¡(fâ¢(ğ‘¸C(1)â¢ğ’™(1)))+ğ”¼ğ’™(2)â¢logâ¡(1âˆ’fâ¢(ğ‘¸C(2)â¢ğ’™(2)))subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¸C1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¸C2superscriptsubscriptğ‘¸P1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¸P1subscriptğ‘“subscriptğ”¼superscriptğ’™1ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘¸C1superscriptğ’™1subscriptğ”¼superscriptğ’™21ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘¸C2superscriptğ’™2\displaystyle\min_{{\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm C}}^{(1)},{\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm C}}^{(2% )}{\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm P}}^{(1)},{\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm P}}^{(1)}}\max_{f}~{}% \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{x}^{(1)}}\log\left(f({\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm C}}^{(1)}{% \boldsymbol{x}}^{(1)})\right)+\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{x}^{(2)}}\log\left(1-f({% \boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm C}}^{(2)}{\boldsymbol{x}}^{(2)})\right)roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ğ”¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( italic_f ( bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) + roman_ğ”¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( 1 - italic_f ( bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) )
+Î»â¢âˆ‘q=12â„›â¢(ğ‘¸C((q)))+Ï‰â¢âˆ‘q=12â„›â¢(ğ‘¸P((q)))+Ïâ¢âˆ‘q=12HSICâ¢(ğ‘¸C(q)â¢ğ’™(q),ğ‘¸P(q)â¢ğ’™(q)),ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘12â„›superscriptsubscriptğ‘¸Cğ‘ğœ”superscriptsubscriptğ‘12â„›superscriptsubscriptğ‘¸Pğ‘ğœŒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘12HSICsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¸Cğ‘superscriptğ’™ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¸Pğ‘superscriptğ’™ğ‘\displaystyle+\lambda\sum_{q=1}^{2}{\cal R}\left({\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm C}}^{((q% ))}\right)+\omega\sum_{q=1}^{2}{\cal R}\left({\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm P}}^{((q))}% \right)+\rho\sum_{q=1}^{2}{\rm HSIC}(\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm C}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{x% }^{(q)},\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm P}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}),+ italic_Î» âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R ( bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ( italic_q ) ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_Ï‰ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R ( bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ( italic_q ) ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_Ï âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_HSIC ( bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (6es)

where, first two term are adversarial loss for distribution matching. The constraint on (6erd) and (6ere) are enforced as â„›â¢(ğ‘¸C(q))â„›superscriptsubscriptğ‘¸Cğ‘{\cal R}({\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm C}}^{(q)})caligraphic_R ( bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and â„›â¢(ğ‘¸C(q))â„›superscriptsubscriptğ‘¸Cğ‘{\cal R}({\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm C}}^{(q)})caligraphic_R ( bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) respectively, where â„›â¢(ğ‘¸(q))=â€–ğ‘¸(q)â¢ğ”¼â¢[ğ’™(q)â¢(ğ’™(q))âŠ¤]â¢(ğ‘¸(q))âŠ¤âˆ’ğ‘°â€–F2â„›superscriptğ‘¸ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ’™ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptğ’™ğ‘topsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘topğ‘°2F{\cal R}({\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)})=\|{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}\mathbb{E}[{% \boldsymbol{x}}^{(q)}({\boldsymbol{x}}^{(q)})^{\top}]({\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)})^% {\top}-\bm{I}\|^{2}_{\rm F}caligraphic_R ( bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = âˆ¥ bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ğ”¼ [ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ( bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_I âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The constraint on (6erc) is realized with Hilbert-Schmidt Independence Criterion (HSIC) [71]. HSIC measures the independence between two distribution. So, we minimize HSIC between estimated shared component and estimated private component to promote independence between shared and private components.

We show that under some reasonable conditions the block ğ’‘(q)superscriptğ’‘ğ‘\bm{p}^{(q)}bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can also be learned up to a matrix multiplication:

{mdframed}

[backgroundcolor=gray!10,topline=false, rightline=false, leftline=false, bottomline=false]

Theorem 6.

Assume that the blocks ğœğœ\bm{c}bold_italic_c, ğ©(1)superscriptğ©1\bm{p}^{(1)}bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ©(2)superscriptğ©2\bm{p}^{(2)}bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are statistically independent, i.e., pâ¢(ğœ,ğ©(1),ğ©(2))=pâ¢(ğœ)â¢pâ¢(ğ©(1))â¢pâ¢(ğ©(2))ğ‘ğœsuperscriptğ©1superscriptğ©2ğ‘ğœğ‘superscriptğ©1ğ‘superscriptğ©2p(\bm{c},\bm{p}^{(1)},\bm{p}^{(2)})=p({\bm{c}})p({\bm{p}^{(1)}})p(\bm{p}^{(2)})italic_p ( bold_italic_c , bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_p ( bold_italic_c ) italic_p ( bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_p ( bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Then, if one of the following holds:

  • (i)

    AssumptionÂ 1 and assumptions in TheoremÂ 1 are satisfied, and (6er) is solved yielding solutions ğ‘¸^C(q)subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘¸ğ‘C\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}_{\rm C}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ‘¸^P(q)subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘¸ğ‘P\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}_{\rm P}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

  • (ii)

    AssumptionÂ 2 is satisfied and has same mixing matrix ğ‘¨(q)=ğ‘¨superscriptğ‘¨ğ‘ğ‘¨\boldsymbol{A}^{(q)}=\boldsymbol{A}bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_A and (6er) with ğ‘¸P(q)=ğ‘¸Psuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¸Pğ‘subscriptğ‘¸P\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm P}^{(q)}=\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm P}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ‘¸C(q)=ğ‘¸Csuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¸Cğ‘subscriptğ‘¸C\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm C}^{(q)}=\boldsymbol{Q}_{\rm C}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is solved yielding ğ‘¸^C(q)subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘¸ğ‘C\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}_{\rm C}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ‘¸^P(q)subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘¸ğ‘P\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}_{\rm P}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the solutions.

  • (iii)

    AssumptionÂ 1 is satisfied and dCsubscriptğ‘‘Cd_{\rm C}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT paired samples (ğ’™â„“(1),ğ’™â„“(2))superscriptsubscriptğ’™â„“1superscriptsubscriptğ’™â„“2(\boldsymbol{x}_{\ell}^{(1)},\boldsymbol{x}_{\ell}^{(2)})( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) are available (weak supervision), and denote ğ‘¸^C(q)subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘¸ğ‘C\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}_{\rm C}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ‘¸^P(q)subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘¸ğ‘P\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}_{\rm P}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the solutions after solving (6er).

Then, we have ğ^C(q)â¢ğ±(q)=ğš¯â¢ğœsubscriptsuperscript^ğğ‘Csuperscriptğ±ğ‘ğš¯ğœ\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}_{\rm C}\bm{x}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}\bm{c}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ bold_italic_c and ğ^P(q)â¢ğ±(q)=ğšµ(q)â¢ğ©(q),subscriptsuperscript^ğğ‘Psuperscriptğ±ğ‘superscriptğšµğ‘superscriptğ©ğ‘\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}_{\rm P}\bm{x}^{(q)}=\bm{\Xi}^{(q)}\bm{p}^{(q)},% ~{}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , for some invertible ğšµ(q)superscriptğšµğ‘\bm{\Xi}^{(q)}bold_Î start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all q=1,2.ğ‘12q=1,2.italic_q = 1 , 2 .

Proof.

For each case in Theorem.Â 6 (i) - (iii), we can prove

ğ’„^(q)=ğ‘¸^C(q)â¢ğ’™(q)=ğš¯â¢ğ’„,q=1,2formulae-sequencesuperscript^ğ’„ğ‘subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘¸ğ‘Csuperscriptğ’™ğ‘ğš¯ğ’„ğ‘12\displaystyle\widehat{\bm{c}}^{(q)}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}_{\rm C}\bm{% x}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}\bm{c},~{}q=1,2over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ bold_italic_c , italic_q = 1 , 2 (6et)

using TheoremsÂ 1-3. The proofs are referred to Appendix B-D.

Let us denote

ğ’‘^(q)superscript^ğ’‘ğ‘\displaystyle\widehat{\bm{p}}^{(q)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =ğ‘¸^P(q)â¢ğ’™(q)=ğ‘¸^P(q)â¢ğ‘¨(q)â¢[ğ’„ğ’‘(q)]=ğ‘¯(q)â¢[ğ’„ğ’‘(q)],absentsuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘¸Pğ‘superscriptğ’™ğ‘subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘¸ğ‘Psuperscriptğ‘¨ğ‘matrixğ’„superscriptğ’‘ğ‘superscriptğ‘¯ğ‘matrixğ’„superscriptğ’‘ğ‘\displaystyle=\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}_{\rm P}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{x}^{(q)}=% \widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}_{\rm P}\boldsymbol{A}^{(q)}\begin{bmatrix}% \boldsymbol{c}\\ \boldsymbol{p}^{(q)}\end{bmatrix}=\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}\begin{bmatrix}% \boldsymbol{c}\\ \boldsymbol{p}^{(q)}\end{bmatrix},= over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_c end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] = bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_c end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] ,

where ğ‘¯(q)=ğ‘¸^P(q)â¢ğ‘¨(q)âˆˆâ„dP(q)Ã—(dC+dP(q))superscriptğ‘¯ğ‘subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘¸ğ‘Psuperscriptğ‘¨ğ‘superscriptâ„superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘Pğ‘subscriptğ‘‘Csuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‘Pğ‘\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}_{\rm P}\boldsymbol{A}^{(q)% }\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\rm P}^{(q)}\times(d_{\rm C}+d_{\rm P}^{(q)})}bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— ( italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that the constraint (6erc) implies that the mutual information between ğ’‘^(q)superscript^ğ’‘ğ‘\widehat{\bm{p}}^{(q)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ’„^(q)superscript^ğ’„ğ‘\widehat{\bm{c}}^{(q)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is zero, i.e.,

We have that ğ’„^(q)=ğš¯â¢ğ’„âŸ¹ğ’„=ğš¯âˆ’1â¢ğ’„^(q),âˆ€qformulae-sequencesuperscript^ğ’„ğ‘ğš¯ğ’„ğ’„superscriptğš¯1superscript^ğ’„ğ‘for-allğ‘\widehat{\bm{c}}^{(q)}=\bm{\Theta}\bm{c}\implies\bm{c}=\bm{\Theta}^{-1}% \widehat{\bm{c}}^{(q)},\forall qover^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î˜ bold_italic_c âŸ¹ bold_italic_c = bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_q. Using data processing inequality [72, Theorem 2.8.1], we get

I(ğ’‘^(q);ğ’„^(q))â‰¥I(ğ’‘^(q);ğš¯âˆ’1ğ’„^(q))=I(ğ’‘^(q);ğ’„)).\displaystyle I(\widehat{\bm{p}}^{(q)};\widehat{\bm{c}}^{(q)})\geq I(\widehat{% \bm{p}}^{(q)};\bm{\Theta}^{-1}\widehat{\bm{c}}^{(q)})=I(\widehat{\bm{p}}^{(q)}% ;\bm{c})).italic_I ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¥ italic_I ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; bold_Î˜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_I ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; bold_italic_c ) ) .

Since mutual information is always non-negative, the above implies that Iâ¢(ğ’‘^(q);ğ’„)=0ğ¼superscript^ğ’‘ğ‘ğ’„0I(\widehat{\bm{p}}^{(q)};\bm{c})=0italic_I ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; bold_italic_c ) = 0. This implies that ğ’‘^(q)=ğ‘¯(q)â¢[ğ’„ğ’‘(q)]superscript^ğ’‘ğ‘superscriptğ‘¯ğ‘matrixğ’„superscriptğ’‘ğ‘\widehat{\bm{p}}^{(q)}=\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}\begin{bmatrix}\boldsymbol{c}\\ \boldsymbol{p}^{(q)}\end{bmatrix}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_c end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] is independent of ğ’„ğ’„\boldsymbol{c}bold_italic_c. Hence, ğ‘¯(q)[1:dC]=0,âˆ€q\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}[1:d_{\rm C}]=0,\forall qbold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ 1 : italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = 0 , âˆ€ italic_q.

Therefore ğ’‘^(q)=ğ‘¯(q)[dC+1:dC+dP(q)]ğ’‘(q)=ğšµ(q)ğ’‘(q),âˆ€q\widehat{\boldsymbol{p}}^{(q)}=\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}[d_{\rm C}+1:d_{\rm C}+d_{% \rm P}^{(q)}]\boldsymbol{p}^{(q)}=\bm{\Xi}^{(q)}\boldsymbol{p}^{(q)},\forall qover^ start_ARG bold_italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 : italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Î start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_q, where ğšµ(q)=ğ‘¯(q)[dC+1:dC+dP(q)]\bm{\Xi}^{(q)}=\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}[d_{\rm C}+1:d_{\rm C}+d_{\rm P}^{(q)}]bold_Î start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 : italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]. Note that ğ‘¯(q)superscriptğ‘¯ğ‘\boldsymbol{H}^{(q)}bold_italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is full row-rank because of constraint (6ere). This implies that ğšµ(q),q=1,2formulae-sequencesuperscriptğšµğ‘ğ‘12\bm{\Xi}^{(q)},q=1,2bold_Î start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_q = 1 , 2 are invertible matrices.

This concludes the proof.

âˆ

H.1 Validation of TheoremÂ 6

Fig.Â 7 presents numerical validation for TheoremÂ 6.

Hyperparameter Setting

The hyperparameter setting is the same as mentioned in Appendix.Â F. We solve (H) to obtain ğ‘¸^C(q)subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘¸ğ‘C\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}_{\rm C}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ‘¸^P(q)subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘¸ğ‘P\widehat{\boldsymbol{Q}}^{(q)}_{\rm P}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to recover the shared and private components, respectively. For learning ğ‘¸P(q)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘P\boldsymbol{Q}^{(q)}_{\rm P}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we use Adam optimizer and set initial learning rates to be 0.0010.0010.0010.001. Also we set the regularization parameter Ï‰=10.0ğœ”10.0\omega=10.0italic_Ï‰ = 10.0 and Ï=50.0ğœŒ50.0\rho=50.0italic_Ï = 50.0.

Data Generation:

We set dC=2subscriptğ‘‘C2d_{\rm C}=2italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 and dP(q)=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘Pğ‘1d_{\rm P}^{(q)}=1italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 as in the previous synthetic experiments. We sample ğ’„âˆ¼VonMisesâ¢(2.5,2.0)similar-toğ’„VonMises2.52.0\bm{c}\sim\texttt{VonMises}(2.5,~{}2.0)bold_italic_c âˆ¼ VonMises ( 2.5 , 2.0 ) The private components are sampled from p(1)âˆ¼Betaâ¢(1.0,3.0)similar-tosuperscriptğ‘1Beta1.03.0p^{(1)}\sim\texttt{Beta}(1.0,~{}3.0)italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ Beta ( 1.0 , 3.0 ) and p(2)âˆ¼Gammaâ¢(0.5,3.0)similar-tosuperscriptğ‘2Gamma0.53.0p^{(2)}\sim\texttt{Gamma}(0.5,~{}3.0)italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ Gamma ( 0.5 , 3.0 ) distributions. Each element of mixing matrices are sampled from ğ‘¨iâ¢j(q)âˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,1),q=1,2formulae-sequencesimilar-tosuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¨ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘ğ’©01ğ‘12\boldsymbol{A}_{ij}^{(q)}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1),~{}q=1,2bold_italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , 1 ) , italic_q = 1 , 2.

Result:

Fig.Â 7 shows the result for proposed method for private component identification. The first column shows the data domain, the second column shows the true and extracted shared component, and the third and fourth columns shows the true and extracted private components. Especially, the last row of the third and fourth columns shows the plot of ground truth ğ’‘(q)superscriptğ’‘ğ‘\bm{p}^{(q)}bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on xâˆ’limit-fromğ‘¥x-italic_x -axis and ğ’‘^(q)superscript^ğ’‘ğ‘\widehat{\bm{p}}^{(q)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on the y-axis. The plot is approximately a straight line which indicates that the estimated private components p^(q)superscript^ğ‘ğ‘\widehat{p}^{(q)}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are scaled version (i.e., invertible linear transformations) of ground truth private components. This verifies our Theorem 6.
